1.solution: 30...♖xh2†! 31.♔xh2 ♖h8 mate ✓ Black would have been lost without this resource.

3.solution: The bishop on d6 is pinned and Steinitz took advantage of that with 14.♗xf4! exf4 15.e5 ✓ which won a piece.

5.solution: 7.♗xf7† ♔xf7 8.♘xe5†+– ✓ White has won two pawns after 9.♘xg4.

6.solution: 19.♖xc6! bxc6 20.♗a5+– ✓ White emerges with a queen and a knight for two rooks.

7.solution: 27...f3! The queen is overloaded and White loses the bishop on c4: 28.♕xf3 ♖xc4–+ ✓ 27...♖xc4?! 28.♕xc4 f3 29.♕f1⩲ is of course not the way to go.

8.solution: 18...♕xc4! There is a fork on e3 coming up: 19.♕xc4 ♘e3† 20.♔e2 ♘xc4–+ ✓

9.solution: 39.♖xd7! White wins back the piece with a winning advantage. 39...♔xd7 39...♖xb4† captures a pawn, but the a-pawn still decides after: 40.♗xb4 ♔xd7 41.♔b5+– ✓ 40.♔xb5+– ✓

11.solution: 34.♗e4! The only drawing move, and easy to find, as Black’s mate threat means White has no other sensible try. 34.♖g1?? loses to everything, but is mated most swiftly by 34...♕xg2†!. 34...♕xe4 Obviously not 34...♖xe4?? 35.♕f8 mate. 35.♗f6† ♗xf6 36.♕xf6† ✓ ½–½ White has a perpetual on f6 and f7.

13.descr: Isidor Gunsberg – Wilhelm Steinitz, New York (2) 1890
13.solution: 18...♘c3! The queen can’t move and keep the bishop on d2 defended, and 19.♗xc3 ♗xc1–+ ✓ lost an exchange (0–1, 39 moves).

14.solution: 20...♖xd3! Breaking open the king’s position to close out the game. 21.♗g2 Or 21.♕xd3 ♕e1† ✓ with mate on the next move. 21...♖hd8 There is nothing White can do against the threats to penetrate on d1 or d2. The game ended after: 22.a4 ♖d1† 23.♖xd1 ♖xd1† 24.♕xd1 ♘xd1 0–1

15.descr: Wilhelm Steinitz – Dirk van Foreest, Haarlem (simul) 1896
15.solution: 38...♕xf1†! ✓Steinitz’s previous move, 38.♕c4-d5, was a grave blunder. 39.♔xf1 ♖e1 mate

16.solution: 9.♘xg5! Not recapturing would be equivalent to resignation, but Black is mated if he takes the knight: 9...fxg5 9...♕e7+– and White won after 26 moves. 10.♕h5† ✓ ♔e7 There are several ways to mate or pick up material. The quickest mate is: 11.♕f7† ♔d6 12.e5† ♘xe5 13.dxe5† ♔xe5 14.♕d5† ♔f6 15.♕xg5 mate

17.solution: 10.♘xa7†! White wins an important pawn after: 10...♘xa7 11.♗xa6† ✓ (1–0, 25 moves)

18.solution: 6.♗xf7†! Not the only time Steinitz executed this combination. White wins two pawns after: 6...♔xf7 7.♘xe5†+– ✓

19.solution: Black is two pawns up, but that doesn’t stop him from being precise: 27...♖xe3! 28.♕xb4 28.♕xe3 ♕c2 mate ✓ 28...♖xe2–+ ✓ White resigned five moves later.

20.solution: 6.♘xg5! Black cannot take back: 6...fxg5 Black instead allowed a forced mate after 6...h6. 7.♕h5† ✓ ♔e7 8.♕f7† ♔d6 And for instance: 9.e5† ♘xe5 10.♕d5† ♔e7 11.♕xe5 mate

21.solution: 5.♘xg5! fxg5 6.♕h5† ♔e7 7.♕xg5† ✓ ♔e8 8.♕h5†! Imprecise is 8.♕e5†?! ♕e7 9.♕xh8 ♕xe4†+– with some slight counterplay. 8...♔e7 9.♕e5†+– White picks up the rook on h8.

22.solution: 7.♘xe5! A surprisingly common theme in Lasker’s games. 7...d5 7...fxe5 8.♕h5† g6 (8...♔e7 9.♕xe5 mate) 9.♕xe5† ♕e7 10.♕xh8+– ✓ 8.♕h5† Or just as good is: 8.♖e1 fxe5 9.♖xe5† ♔d7 10.♗g5!+– 8...g6 One source gives this game as played in New York 1911, with 8...♔e7 9.♘f7? ♕e8? 0–1 (??) as the final moves, none of which makes any sense. 9.♘xg6 hxg6 10.♕xh8 ✓ Or 10.♖e1† first. 10...dxc4 There are many ways to win and you don’t have to decide in advance. Easiest is: 11.♖e1† ♔f7 12.♗h6+–

23.solution: 20.♖xd5! ♖xd5 21.♕xd5+– ✓ White has won a piece, since Black cannot recapture.

24.descr: Emanuel Lasker – Efim Bogoljubov, Atlantic Ocean 1924
24.solution: 19.♘a4! ✓ The rook is trapped and the c5-pawn is threatened. 19...♖a3 20.♕b2 Lasker played 20.♘xc5± and won after 22 moves, but the text is better. 20...b4 21.♕xe5± Black loses a second pawn.

25.solution: 38...♖xe5! 39.♕xe5 ♕f3† 40.♔g1 ♕xd1† ✓ 41.♔f2 ♕d7∓ It is probably a theoretical draw, but that does not change the verdict during a game between humans (0–1, 55 moves).

26.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – C.E. Watson, Schenectady 1909
26.solution: White has a minor piece less, but can more than make up for it with the following double threat: 30.♖f6! ♘xf6 31.♖xf6 ✓ ♕h5 32.♗d1 Not necessary, but a luxury White can afford. 32.♘xe6 and 32.♖xe6 are also winning. 32...♕e8 33.♖xe6+– Black is an exchange up, but since he has no chance against all the pawns and an invasion on the kingside, he resigned now.

27.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – E.B. Schrader, Saint Louis (simul) 1909
27.solution: 23.♕xh5! The fork on f6 gains a piece. 23...♕xh5 24.♘f6† ♔h8 25.♘xh5+– ✓

28.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – D.W. Pomeroy, Saint Louis (simul) 1909
28.solution: 21...♖xg2†! ✓ White resigned, since he is mated after: 22.♔xg2 ♖g8† Or 22...♕g6†. 23.♔h1 ♕xh6† 24.♕h5 ♕xh5 mate

29.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – T.A. Carter, Saint Louis (simul) 1909

30.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Frank Marshall, New York 1910
30.solution: 28.♘f6†! Black could have resigned here, but continued until move 43. 28...gxf6 29.♖xe8†+– ✓

31.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Luis Piazzini, Buenos Aires 1911
31.solution: 34...♖xh4†! Black can also start by exchanging on c4. 35.gxh4 g3† 36.♔g1 gxf2† ✓ 37.♔xf2–+ Instead of being an exchange up, Black is a rook up.

32.solution: 35...♖xf2! Defending against the double threat and getting a queen ending with two healthy pawns and a safe king. 36.♕xf2 ♕xe6†–+ ✓

33.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Will Randolph, New York 1912
33.solution: 31.♕xg5! 31.♖xg8† ♖xg8 32.♕xg8† is another way to do the same thing. 31...hxg5 32.♖xg8† Black resigned since he will be a piece down: 32...♔xg8 33.♘f6† ♔f7 34.♘xd7+– ✓

34.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – F.S. Dunkelsbuhler, London (simul) 1913
34.solution: 15.♕xd5!+– Black resigned, as he is mated after: 15...♕xd5 16.♖e8† ♖f8 17.♖xf8 mate ✓

35.descr: Albert Beauregard Hodges – Jose Raul Capablanca, New York 1915
35.solution: 24...♗xe4! White’s pieces are overloaded and Black won a pawn after: 25.♗xe4 ♖xc4–+ ✓

36.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Einar Michelsen, New York (simul) 1915
36.solution: 35.♖xe6†! ♔xe6 36.♗d5† ♔d6 37.♗xg8+– ✓ Black’s rook is unable to fight against the two passed pawns. The final moves were: 37...♖e7 38.c5† ♔c6 39.♗d5† ♔b5 40.g6 1–0

37.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – N.N., New York 1918

38.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – J. Birch, Glasgow 1919
38.solution: 31...♖xd3! 31...♕h1†?? 32.♕xh1 would be a terrible blunder. The game move wins a piece after: 32.cxd3 ♕e5† 33.♔d2 ♕xa1–+ ✓

39.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – G.H. Hadland, Thornton Heath 1919
39.solution: 21.♗xh7†! ♔h8 Or 21...♔xh7 22.g6†+– ✓ with a fork. 22.♗g6 And White won.

40.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Milan Vidmar, London 1922
40.solution: 22.♗h7†! 22.♕xd7 ♖xc2 is equal. 22...♔xh7 23.♖xc8 ♖xc8 24.♕xc8+– ✓ White is an exchange up.

41.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – W. Malowan, New York (simul) 1922
41.solution: 36.♘xf7†?! looks like a combination and was played in the game, but Black had 36...♖xf7 37.g6 ♖xf5†! 38.♖xf5 ♖g7 when he collects the g-pawn with a draw. Instead normal moves give two points. A good choice is 36.f6 ♖g6 37.♗f4!+– when Black’s rooks are trapped and he can’t sacrifice the exchange in a good way.

43.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Jacques Mieses, Bad Kissingen 1928
43.solution: 31.♖xb6! Winning a second pawn. 31...axb4 Or 31...♖xb6 32.♘xd5+– ✓ with a fork. 32.♖xb7 ♖xb7 33.♖xb4 1–0 The endgame is hopeless for Black.

44.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Arpad Vajda, Budapest 1929
44.solution: 22.♗xa6! White wins a pawn due to: 22...bxa6 23.♖c6† ♔e7 24.♖xb6+– ✓

45.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Albert Becker, Karlsbad 1929
45.solution: 17.♘xh7! f5 Instead 17...♔xh7 can be met by 18.♘f6†+– ✓ with a discovered check, or 18.♘c3†+–. 18.♘hg5 18.♘xf8 fxe4 19.♗c4 is also winning. In the game, Black resigned due to: 18...fxe4 19.♗xe4 The bishop on b7 is doomed. (White could also go for the king with 19.♗c4+–, forcing Black to give up his queen.)

46.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Manuel Larrea, Mexico (simul) 1933
46.solution: 11.♘db5! 11.♘cb5 is the same. 11...axb5 12.♘xb5 ♗g3† Regaining the pawn does little to alleviate the real problems of the black position – his weaknesses on the dark squares (and the b6-pawn) and lack of development. 13.hxg3 ♕xg3† 14.♗f2+– ✓

47.descr: Vera Menchik – Jose Raul Capablanca, Margate 1935

48.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Grigory Levenfish, Moscow 1935

49.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Mikhail Botvinnik, Moscow 1936
49.solution: 34.♖xd5! White wins a pawn, since 34...cxd5 35.♗xd5†+– ✓ is a fork.

50.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Guillermo Vassaux, Buenos Aires (ol) 1939

51.solution: 16...♗xg2! Highlighting the usefulness of the active d4-rook. 17.♕g3 17.♕xg2 ♖g4–+ ✓ pins the queen. 17...♖g4 ✓ 18.♗xc5 ♖xg3 19.fxg3 ♖e8–+

54.descr: J. Goldfarb – Alexander Alekhine, St Petersburg 1909

55.solution: White reduces the material deficit from a piece to an exchange with: 21.♖xf5! gxf5 22.♕xg7± ✓ Considering the weak dark squares and exposed king, his position is clearly superior.

56.descr: Alexander Alekhine – Stefan Izbinsky, St Petersburg 1909
56.solution: 19.♗xh7†! Forcing the king to leave the defence of the rook. 19...♔xh7 20.♕xf8+– ✓

57.descr: V. Rozanov/N. Tselikov – Alexander Alekhine, Moscow 1915
57.solution: 27...♕xe1†! 27...♖xf3 28.♖f1 ♕xf1†! (28...♕xe2?? 29.♕c8† ♖f8 30.♕xf8 mate) 29.♗xf1 ♘f2† 30.♔g2 ♘xh3 31.♔xf3 ♘g5† is also winning for Black, although it doesn’t look so simple with White’s king active after 32.♔f4 ♘f7 33.♔f5 (one point). 28.♘xe1 ♘f2† 29.♔g2 ♘xh3 30.♘f3 30.♔xh3 ♖e8!–+ ✓ 30...♖xf3 Black could also have achieved a winning position by going for the a-pawn, but this is simple. 31.♗xf3 31.♔xf3 ♘g1†–+ ✓ 31...♘g5–+ ✓ 0–1

58.solution: 15.♘xe4! ♗xe4 16.c5 A discovered attack, winning the bishop. 16...♗xc5 17.♕xe4+– ✓

59.solution: 18.♘xf5†! Not 18.♗xf5? ♖h4 (18...♖xg3∓) 19.♘h5 ♕h8 and Black wins a piece. 18...exf5 Instead Alekhine tried 18...♔f8, but White has several ways to win, for instance 19.♘xd6 ♖h4 trapping the queen, but to no avail. 20.♕xf7† ♕xf7 21.♘xf7+– White has won three pawns (1–0, 42 moves). 19.♘xd5†+– ✓ It’s a fork.

60.solution: 15.♘xd5! cxd5? Yates avoided this with 15...♗d6, but after 16.♗xd6 ✓ cxd5+– he had no compensation whatsoever for the lost pawn. 16.♗c7+– ✓ The queen is trapped.

61.solution: 25...♗xf2!⩱ White can’t take back due to: 26.♕xf2? ♕xf2† 27.♔xf2 ♖d2† 28.♔e3 ♖xc2–+ ✓

62.descr: Roberto Grau – Alexander Alekhine, San Remo 1930
62.solution: 37...♖xf3! 38.gxf3 38.♖xf3 ♕d1† 39.♖f1 ♕xf1 mate ✓ 38...♕c2 ✓ 0–1 There is no defence against the mate.

64.solution: 19.♗g6! fxg6 19...♕a5 avoids mate, but Black is completely lost after 20.♗xf7† ♔d8 followed by any decent queen move. 20.♕xg6 mate ✓

66.solution: 20.♖d8†! 20.♕xb7 ♖xb7 21.♗xe5 is also good (White will soon be two pawns up) but only the game move forces resignation. Note that after 20.♕xb7 ♖xb7 White should avoid pinning the bishop with 21.♖d8† ♗f8 22.♗a3 since Black can struggle on with: 22...♘d7! Nevertheless, White gets a rook ending a pawn up that looks winning. 20...♗f8 20...♖xd8 21.♕xb7+– ✓ 21.♕xf6+– ✓

67.solution: 11.♘xf7! Classical destruction of the f7-e6 formation. 11...♔xf7 12.♕xe6† 1–0 Black foresaw 12...♔g7 13.♕f7 mate ✓

68.solution: 31.♗xf6!± ✓ White wins a pawn since Black cannot take back on f6.

70.solution: 9.♗xh7† ♘xh7 10.♗xe7 ✓ ♖e8 11.♗h4 dxc4± Alekhine was not worried about giving back the pawn, since he gets a strong centre. If he was worried, he could have started with 9.cxd5±, which is equally strong. (1–0, 40 moves)

71.descr: Alexander Alekhine – J.M. De Cossio, San Sebastian (simul) 1944
71.solution: 9.♘f6†! gxf6 10.♗xf6 ✓ 1–0 There is no defence against the mate on g7.

72.solution: 14.♘h6†! gxh6 15.♗xf6+– ✓ White checkmates or wins the queen.

74.solution: 18...♕xh2†! Exchanging queens and consolidating the material advantage. 19.♔xh2 ♘g4† 20.♔g3 ♘xh6–+ ✓

75.solution: 19...♗xg2! 20.♔xg2 ♖g6†–+ ✓ Black wins the queen or the rook on f1.

76.descr: Max Euwe – Efim Bogoljubov, Maehrisch Ostrau 1923
76.solution: 13...♕xc3! 14.♕xc3 ♘e4† Black wins back his sacrificed piece, leaving him a pawn up. 15.♔f1 ♘xc3⩱ ✓

77.solution: 27.♕xf6†! ♔xf6 28.♘xe4† ♔e5 29.♘xc5 bxc5 ✓ The pawn ending is winning, unless Black gets time to collect the queenside pawns. And he doesn’t after: 30.♔f1 (or 30.f3)

78.solution: 25...♘xe4 26.♕xe4 ♗d5–+ ✓ If White steps out of the pin with 26.♔h2, there are many moves that keep the pawn: 26...f5, 26...♗d5 or even 26...♘f6 27.♘xe5 ♘xe5 28.♕xe5 ♗xb3.

79.solution: 20...♖xd3! 21.♖exd3 ♖xd3 Or 21...♗xc4 first makes no difference. 22.♖xd3 ♗xc4 23.♔e2–+ ✓ An extra pawn in a pawn ending wins, unless there are some special circumstances.

82.descr: Dirk van Foreest – Max Euwe, Netherlands 1932

84.descr: Max Euwe – Efim Bogoljubov, Bad Nauheim/Stuttgart/Garmisch 1937
84.solution: 26...♘xd4! 26...♗xd4 picks up the pawn, but not the exchange. Black is not clearly winning yet (zero points). 27.♖xd4 ♗xd4 White cannot take in any way due to mate on e1: 28.♖xd4 ♕e1 mate ✓

85.solution: 13.♘xe5! ♘e6 13...fxe5 14.♗g5†+– ✓ 14.♘d3!+– ✓ White is not only a pawn up, Black is also far behind in development.

87.descr: Theo van Scheltinga – Max Euwe, Amsterdam 1948
87.solution: 38.♗xe6! ♘xe6 Keeping the knight and setting up a blockade on the e-file was not realistic, since White has an f-pawn as well. 39.♕f5† Or 39.♕e4†. 39...♔h8 40.♕xe6± ✓ White’s winning chances should be bigger than Black’s drawing chances, although the game ended in a draw.

89.solution: 25...♕xe5! Removing the defender of the e2-square. 26.dxe5 ♘e2† 27.♔h2 ♘xg3–+ ✓

90.solution: 35.♗xf6! ♗xf6 36.e7† ♔g7 37.exd8=♕+– ✓ Opposite-coloured bishops normally improve the drawing chances of the player who has sacrificed material, but Black did not sacrifice the exchange here – he lost it. And without active pieces, he cannot create anything on the dark squares. Instead White’s active pieces and advantage in terrain give him an even greater advantage.

91.solution: 19...♗xb2! 20.♕xb2 ♖d1† 21.♗f1 ♖xf1† 22.♔g2 ♖d1∓ ✓ Black has won a pawn (0–1, 35 moves).

93.solution: 17...♖xe3! 18.♕xe3 Botvinnik played 18.♖xg7†–+ and resigned after 45 moves. 18...♗f4–+ ✓ There is both a fork and a pin.

94.solution: 34...♗e4 White resigned. 35.♗xe4 35.♖xd2 exd2–+ ✓ and the pawn queens, or 35.♖cxe3 ♗xe3 36.♖xd2 ♗xf3† 37.♔xf3 ♗xd2 ✓ and Black is winning. 35...♖xe2†–+ ✓ The bishop will have to sacrifice itself for the e-pawn.

95.solution: 37.♕xc7!+– ✓ White wins two pawns due to the back-rank mate (1–0, 47 moves). 37.e5 also looks promising, as it opens up for an attack against h7, but 37...♖d2! 38.♕f5 g6 39.♕xf6† ♕xf6 40.exf6+– limits White’s advantage to only a winning endgame.

96.solution: 16.♘xd5! Threatening the queen with check. 16...cxd5 17.♕xe5 ♕xe5 18.♗xe5+– ✓ White has won a pawn with a dominant position (1–0, 24 moves).

97.solution: 17...♕xh3†! 18.♔xh3 ♘xf2† 19.♔g2 ♘xd1 20.♖xd1–+ ✓ It’s an exchange and a pawn.

100.solution: 19.♖d8†! ♔e7 The point is 19...♔xd8 20.♘xf7† ♔e7 21.♘xe5+– ✓. 20.♖xh8+– ✓ The game finished with: 20...♕xg5 21.♕d2 1–0

101.solution: 35.♕xd5! ♘xd5 The game move 35...♗f4 is of course hopeless as well (1–0, 41 moves). 36.♖e8† ♔h7 37.♖h8 mate ✓

103.descr: Mikhail Tal – Nino Kirov, Novi Sad 1974
103.solution: 20.♗xh7†! 20.♕h5 ♘f5 21.g4 does not win a piece, and even loses after 21...♖h6. 20...♔xh7 21.♕h5† ♖h6 22.♕xc5± ✓ White has won a pawn, but it is only a flank pawn.

105.solution: 31...♖xe2! 32.♖xe2 d3 33.♖xe5 White resigned after 33.♖c3 dxe2† 34.♔e1 ♗b4. 33...dxc2†–+ ✓ Black gets a second queen.

107.solution: 12.♘xf7! ♔xf7 12...♕e7 and White won after 30 moves. 13.♕xe6† ♔f8 14.♕f7 mate ✓

108.solution: 28...♖e1†! 0–1 White resigned due to: 29.♔h2 29.♖xe1 ♕xd4–+ ✓ 29...♕xd4 30.♖xd4 ♖xa1–+ ✓ The game will appear again later in the book.

109.solution: 27...♘xf4! 28.exf4 ♖xe2 ✓ Black is clearly better, but White managed to hold (41 moves).

110.solution: 38.♗xc4!+– 38.♖xe6 fxe6 39.♗xc4? (39.♖xe6 ♔h7=) 39...♕xe1†–+ Black cannot take the bishop due to: 38...♗xc4 38...♖d6 39.♗xe6 was just hopeless (1–0, 41 moves). 39.♖e8† ♖xe8 40.♖xe8† ♔h7 41.♖h8 mate ✓

111.solution: 28...♗xg4! 29.♕xg4 Petrosian fought on with 29.♕g3–+ but he regretted 28.g4? for sure (0–1, 38 moves). 29...♖g6–+ ✓

112.solution: 32...d4! 33.♖xd4 33.♕e1 d3–+ and the pawn supported by pieces is too strong. 33...♕b6 ✓ 0–1 Or 33...♕a7–+, but not 33...♗f6? 34.♖xd7!∓. If you chose a slower way to advance the pawn on the 32nd move, such as 32...♗f6 or 32...♕a7†, you also get full points.

113.solution: 29.♘xd5! 29.♗a6?! ♖d8⩲ 29...♖xc2 30.♘f6† Getting out of Dodge before recapturing the rook. 30...♔f8 31.♖xc2+– ✓ In addition to an extra pawn, White’s pieces are much stronger, for instance the bishop on e8 is dominated (1–0, 33 moves).

114.solution: 24.♘fxe6!+– There are a few alternatives with the same idea: 24.♘gxe6+– or 24.axb5 ♗xb5 25.♘gxe6+–. 24...♘xe6 25.♗xd5+– ✓ Since the c6-knight cannot retreat on account of the a8-rook, White is regaining at least the piece, with a winning position (1–0, 30 moves).

115.solution: 33.♕g8†! A magnet sacrifice leading to a quick mate. Black resigned, rather than face: 33...♔xg8 34.♗e6† ♔h8 35.♖g8 mate ✓

116.solution: 30.♕h8†! 30.♘xf7?! ♕xe3!⩲ In the game, Black resigned. He is a piece down after: 30...♔xh8 31.♘xf7† ♔g7 32.♘xg5+– ✓

117.solution: 39.♖xg7†! 39.♕e8 eyes the pawn on e4, but wins only because White has the same rook sacrifice later. But not: 39.♘f6†?? ♖xf6–+ 39...♖xg7 40.♘f6 mate ✓

118.descr: Dragoljub Janosevic – Tigran Petrosian, Lone Pine 1978

119.solution: 35.♖xd4! Black resigned as it’s mate: 35...♖xd4 36.♖xe5† ♔xg4 37.f3 mate ✓ Or 37.h3 mate.

120.solution: 26.♖xe4! ♕xe4 26...♕g6+– is hopeless for Black when he has lost his only trump, the passed e-pawn (1–0, 28 moves). 27.♕f7† ♔h8 28.♕f8† ♖xf8 29.♖xf8 mate ✓

121.descr: John Spencer Purdy – Boris Spassky, Antwerp 1955
121.solution: 10...d3! The bishop on b2 is en prise and 11.♗xg7 dxe2–+ ✓ is an intermediate move that wins a piece.

122.solution: 38...♖f1†! Other moves are obviously also winning, but mate-in-two should be seen and played here. 39.♔xf1 ♕e1 mate ✓

123.solution: 20.♗a6! ♗xa6 Shofman played 20...c6 but was simply a piece down after 21.♗xb7†. 21.♕a8 mate ✓

124.solution: 38.♘xa6! Neatly picking up a pawn due to: 38...♗xa6 39.♖b6† ♔d7 40.♖xa6+– ✓

125.solution: 21.♖xf8†! ♖xf8 22.axb4+– ✓ The two pieces easily outshine the rook.

126.descr: Borislav Ivkov – Boris Spassky, Santa Monica 1966
126.solution: 36...♕xf4! There is a fork on e3 coming up. 37.gxf4 ♘e3† 38.♔g3 ♘xd1–+ ✓

127.solution: 35.♕h6†! Korchnoi did not let his opponent execute the mate: 35...♔xh6 36.♖h1 mate ✓ Or 35...♔g8 36.♖c8† ♖f8 37.♖xf8 mate.

128.solution: Black is winning with many moves, but only one is a forced mate: 32...♕xg1† 33.♔xg1 ♖xg2† 34.♔h1 ♖h2† 35.♔g1 ♖cg2† 36.♔f1 ♗b5† 37.♔e1 ♖h1 mate ✓ Or 37...♖g1 mate.

129.solution: 33.f5! ♗xf5 34.♖e7+– ✓ The queen can no longer defend the bishop.

130.solution: It’s mate in five moves: 30.♗xg6†! 30.♖e2 is winning as well thanks to the continued threat of ♗xg6†. 30...♖xg6 31.♖e7† ♔g8 32.♕xg6† Or 32.♕f7† ♔h8 33.♕h7 mate. 32...♔f8 33.♕g7 mate ✓ Or 33.♕f7 mate.

131.solution: 29...♖xh1! Black gets two pieces for the rook after: 30.♕xh1 ♘xd4 31.cxd4 ♕xd2–+ ✓

132.solution: 85...♕xh6†! 85...♕d2† is the complicated way to draw (zero points). The queen endgame with g- and h-pawns is generally drawn with the defending king in front of the pawns. It surprised the whole Swedish team when we learned this at the 2016 Olympiad in Baku. However, 85...♕d2† should lose in a practical game. First, Black has to find 86.♕f4 ♕d8† 87.♕f6† ♔h7! 88.♕xd8 with stalemate. 86.♔xh6 ✓ ½–½ Stalemate! 86.♔f5 keeps the game going, but it’s an easy draw anyway.

137.descr: Samuel Reshevsky – Robert Fischer, Los Angeles 1961
137.solution: 28...♕xe4! 29.♘xe4 ♘e2† 30.♔h1 ♘xg3† ✓ Black should be winning with the extra exchange, but failed to convert (½–½, 57 moves).

138.solution: 21.♗xg7! exd3 The game ended after 21...♔xg7 22.♘xe4 when either White’s attack or his extra piece would have been enough on their own. 22.f6 Or 22.♗d4+–. 22...dxc2 23.♖h8 mate ✓

139.solution: 24...♘xe3! Black is a piece up, but there is still work to be done. Fischer decided the game on the spot. 25.♕xe3 25.♗xe6 ♕xg2 mate ✓ 25...♗xc4–+ ✓ (0–1, 31 moves)

140.descr: Robert Fischer – John Fuller, Bay City 1963
140.solution: White exploits Black’s last move (14...♘d4) with a simple discovered attack. 15.♘xd4 15.♘f6†? ♕xf6! and White has to play 16.♕xd4⩱. 15...♖xd4 16.♘f6†! ♕xf6 17.♕xd4 ✓ White has a clear advantage and the game ended abruptly after a further blunder by Black: 17...♖d8 18.♕e4 ♗d5? 19.♕xd5 1–0

141.solution: 22.♗xc5! ♗xc5 The game saw 22...♕b8+–. 23.b4+– ✓ ♘d7? The only critical move, but it is simply bad: 24.bxc5 ♘xc5? 25.♕c2+–

142.descr: Robert Fischer – Robert Byrne, New York 1965
142.solution: 12...♗d6! Moving the threatened piece out of danger with a dangerous threat. Not 12...bxc6 13.♗xg4= or 12...♗xe2? 13.♘xe7†±. 13.h3 ♗xe2 14.♘d4 ♗xf1–+ ✓ (0–1, 36 moves)

143.solution: 35.♖xf6! Taking the rook loses the queen, so Black resigned. Instead if White had retreated the rook with, for example, 35.♖h3 then he would still have some work to do, although 1–0 does seem the most probable result (no points). 35...♕xf6 35...♔xf6 36.♗xg5†+– ✓ 36.♘h5†+– ✓

144.descr: Samuel Reshevsky – Robert Fischer, Palma de Mallorca 1970

145.descr: Svetozar Gligoric – Robert Fischer, Palma de Mallorca 1970
145.solution: 29...♘d3! An unexpected fork after White’s last move 29.♖f1-f2?. 30.♕xb6 30.♖xd3 ♕a1† ✓ mating. 30...♘xf2†–+ ✓ Black is a piece up and has the more active heavy pieces. White resigned a few moves later.

146.descr: Vladimir Peresipkin – Anatoly Karpov, Rostov on Don 1971

147.solution: 35.♖g5! Using the fact that the knight on f7 is pinned. 35...♕xg5 35...♘xg5 36.♖xg7† ♔xg7 37.♘xg5+– ✓ and White is up too much material. 36.♘xg5 ✓ ♘xg5 37.d5 1–0

148.solution: 28...♗b6†! The move order 28...♖xf4 doesn’t work as well: 29.♗e6†! ♔h8 30.♘d5∓ Even worse is: 28...♘b2? 29.♕xf5± 29.♔f1 ♖xf4†! 30.gxf4 ♕xf4† ✓ 0–1 Black has a mating attack.

149.solution: 38.♖e7†! The only way to promote the pawn. And not: 38.dxc7? ♖c6∓ 38...♔f8 38...♔f6 39.dxc7+– ✓ 39.dxc7+– ♖c6 40.♖d7 Karpov chose a slower way: 40.♖xh7 ♔e8 41.h4+– 40...♔e8 41.♖d8† ♔e7 42.c8=♕ ♖xc8 43.♖xc8+– ✓

150.solution: 20...♖xe2! 21.♕xe2 ♕xc1† ✓ Black has opened White’s first rank and won a pawn, leaving him up a full exchange, and winning. The game had a quick finish: 22.♕f1 ♕d2 23.cxb6? ♖c8 0–1

151.solution: 38...♘g3†! White resigned in view of 39.hxg3 ♖a8! ✓ with mate.

152.descr: Viktor Korchnoi – Anatoly Karpov, Baguio City (17) 1978

153.solution: 31.♕xc4! Black resigned instead of permitting: 31...bxc4 32.♖xf7 mate ✓

154.solution: 32.♕xd5! Move order is important here. 32.♗h6† ♔e7± 33.♖xd5? (33.♕b4† ♔d7 34.♖d2 ♖xd2 35.♗xd2 ♖g6±) 33...♖xe2†!=, or 32.♕b4†!? ♔g7 33.♕h4 ♖e8!± still with great chances against Black’s exposed king. 32...♕xd5 33.♗h6† 33.♗b4†? ♕c5†= 33...♔e7 34.♖xd5+– ✓ (1–0, 38 moves)

155.solution: 26.♘d5! 26.♘b5 is a worse variant since the queen can escape to e7, but it still gives a winning advantage: 26...♕e7 27.♗xf6 ♕xf6 28.♘xd6+– (full points) 26...♗xb2 26...exd5 27.♗xf6 ♘g6 28.♗xd8+– ✓ 27.♘xc7+– ✓ (1–0, 40 moves)

158.solution: 21.♘d5! Exploiting the claustrophobic queen on e6. 21...♘c5 Black’s alternatives are no better: 21...cxd5 22.cxd5+– ✓, 21...♖b8 22.♘c7+– ✓ or 21...♖c8 22.♘e7†± ✓. 22.♘c7 ♕d7 23.♘xe8± ✓ Karpov saved a draw (42 moves).

159.solution: 33.♕xg6! 1–0 White was winning anyway, but this is too nice to pass up. 33...hxg6 34.♖h4 And 35.♖h8 mate ✓ is unavoidable.

160.descr: Anatoly Karpov – Loek van Wely, Monte Carlo 1997
160.solution: 30.♗h7†! Deflecting the knight or king. 30...♘xh7 30...♔h8 31.♕xf8 mate ✓ 31.♕xd7+– ✓

161.solution: 34...♖xe6! Clearing the back rank in order to force the king to h2, so the bishop falls with check. 35.♖xe6 ♖a1† 35...♕xf4?! 36.♖e8† ♘f8 37.♕h5⩱ 36.♔h2 ♕xf4†–+ ✓ (0–1, 46 moves)

162.descr: Anatoly Karpov – Mikhail Gurevich, Cap d’Agde 2000
162.solution: 37...♗xe3! Using the fact that pins can sometimes become discovered attacks instead. 38.♗xe3?! 38.♗g2 ♗xf2 39.♕xf2∓ 38...♖g1† 39.♖xg1 ♕xh4 40.♗g5 ♕e4†! 41.♗g2 ♕xd4 ✓ White has no time to move the bishop from g2, since the e5-pawn is hanging. After 42.♗f6† ♔g8–+ there is no good discovered check (0–1, 50 moves).

164.solution: 25...♖xd2! 26.♖xd2 After the game move 26.♕h4–+ Black has simply won a piece, so White resigned in a couple of moves. 26...♕xc1†–+ ✓

165.solution: 30.♗b5! The X-ray mate threat wins the bishop. Black resigned instead of allowing: 30...♗xb5 31.♖d8 mate ✓

167.descr: Anatoly Karpov – Ehsan Ghaem Maghami, Teheran 2009

168.solution: 22.♖xc7! 22.♘d4 threatens 23.♘b5 with mate, but Black can defend after 22...♕e7 23.♘b5 c6±. 22...♔xc7 23.♕a7† ✓ 1–0 With the rook coming to c1, the attack will be deadly.

169.solution: 29...♕xc5! ✓ The back-rank mate threat means Black has simply won a rook, leaving him easily winning.

170.solution: 36.♖xe8† ♖xe8 Instead Black soon lost after 36...♔f7+–. 37.♕xf6 ✓ White is mating.

171.solution: 27...♘e3† ✓ 0–1 A discovered attack, which could also be executed with 27...♘f4†–+.

173.solution: 32.♗xc6! ♗xc6 33.♕c7† ♕e7 34.♕xc6± ✓ White is a pawn up with good winning chances.

174.solution: 31...♗xf2! Winning a second pawn due to: 32.♔xf2 ♖h2†–+ ✓

175.solution: 35.♖d4! ✓ 1–0 Mating. 35.♖g7 is a useless intermediate move that allows Black to defend with 35...♗e8 36.♖d4 ♗g6±.

176.solution: 22...♘c5! The pin allows this fork. 23.dxc5 ♖xd3∓ ✓ (0–1, 36 moves)

177.solution: 32...♖xb2 Picking up a pawn with a small tactic gives Black a winning endgame. 33.♖xb2 Instead, White tried to fight with 33.♘b5–+ but in the end it proved fruitless (0–1, 53 moves). 33...♗xc3†–+ ✓

178.solution: White is obviously much better, but cleanest is: 27.♖xd4! Black resigned in view of: 27...exd4 28.♕f5† ♕f7 29.♕c8† ♕e8 30.♕xe8 mate ✓

179.descr: Alexander Khalifman – Gennadi Sosonko, St Petersburg 1997
179.solution: 26.♗f6! The king is too exposed after: 26...gxf6 27.exf6 ✓

180.solution: 37...♖xd4!–+ ✓ Black wins back the rook on c1, so he has just won a piece, and will break through easily.

181.solution: 26.♕xf6†! Other moves take longer to win. 26...♕xf6 27.♖xh7 mate ✓

182.descr: Alexander Khalifman – Christian Gabriel, Bad Wiessee 1998
182.solution: 21.♖xb3! Black resigned since 21...♘xb3 22.♕e6† ♔b8 23.♕xb3+– ✓ is winning, although it wouldn’t have hurt to fight on.

183.solution: 26...♕xg5! Picking up this pawn increases the advantage considerably. 27.♗xg5 White tried to fight on with 27.♖ge1, but resigned a few moves later. 27...♘f2 mate ✓

184.solution: 24.♗h3†! ✓ 1–0 If the king moves, 25.♕e5† picks up the rook on h8 (and mates). If the bishop is taken then 25.♕f8† mates. And finally, anything put in the way will just be taken. Not 24.♖d6? ♕b1† 25.♗f1 ♕h7 26.♗g2 ♕b1†=.

185.descr: Vladimir Kramnik – Dmitry Reinderman, Wijk aan Zee (blitz) 1999

186.solution: 38.♖a8! ♔c7 38...♘xa6 39.♖xa6† leaves White with an easily winning endgame. 39.a7 ♖xb7 40.♖c8†! ✓ 1–0 The pawn promotes.

187.solution: The knight seems to be forced back, but can instead go forward to seemingly protected squares. 20.♘e5! ♖f8 (20...fxe5? 21.♕f7 mate) 21.♘xd7!+– ✓ Black can’t take back since it would leave the rook on a8 unprotected (1–0, 23 moves).

188.solution: 20.e4! The bishop on d6 becomes exposed. 20...♗xe4 20...dxe4 21.♗b5† ♔f8 22.♖xd6+– ✓ 21.♗xe4+– ✓

190.solution: 38.e7! ✓ 1–0 The only defence against 39.♕g7 mate leaves the rook on c8 undefended.

192.solution: 25.♕h6! White removes the queen from danger with a mating threat, leaving the knight on b4 to face the gallows. 25...f6 25...♘xb2 26.♘g5+– ✓ with mate. 26.♖xb4+– ✓

193.solution: 22...♘xe3! ✓ 22...♗xe3†? 23.♗xe3 wins for White. 23.♖xe3 Other moves are no better: 23.♗xe3 ♕xa1–+ or 23...♗xe3† 24.♕xe3 ♕xa1–+. White is so tied up that basically any move wins by eventually bringing one rook into the action. 23...♖fe8 0–1

194.descr: Viswanathan Anand – Jon Ludvig Hammer, Stavanger 2015
194.solution: 34.♗xg6! Winning two more pawns, bringing the total to an overwhelming three. 34...♕xg6 35.♕xe5† ♔g8 36.♕xc5 ✓1–0

196.solution: 34.♖xf4†! ✓ 1–0 Winning the queen. 34.♗xh7 keeps the threat of ♖xf4†, but Black can fight on with 34...♕h3±. 34.♖xh7 allows 34...♖b2!=.

197.solution: 37.♗h5! Exploiting all the pins! 37.♖xf6!? gxf6 38.♗h5 ♕b7 39.♗xf7† ♕xf7 40.♕b6± gives Black good drawing chances in a queen ending a pawn down. 37...g6 37...♘xh5 38.♕xf7† ✓ ♔h8 39.♕e8† ♕f8 40.♖xf8 mate or 37...♕f8 38.♗xf7†+–. 38.♖xf6 ✓ Or 38.♗xg6 hxg6 39.♖xf6+–. In the game, Black resigned in a few moves: 38...♕b7 39.♗d1 b2 40.♕e8† ♔g7 41.♕xf7† 1–0

198.solution: 37...♗xf3! Winning the g2-pawn and an exchange. 37...♖gxg2† 38.♗xg2 ♖xf5 is too kind: 39.♖c1⩱ 38.♖xf3 ♖gxg2† 39.♔h1 ♖h2† 40.♔g1 ♘e2† ✓ 0–1

199.solution: 31.♖e7!+– ✓ Threatening mate, and both defences end up losing the bishop. 31...♖d4 31...♖g6 32.♖dxd7+– 32.♖xd4 cxd4 33.♕xd4 1–0 Double attack.

202.solution: 29...♖xe5! The white queen is doubly pinned and is needed to protect g2. 30.♕xh4 30.♕xe5 ♕xg2 mate ✓ (or 30...♕xd3–+), and 30.♕xg6 ♖xe1 mate ✓ (or 30...♘xg6–+). 30...♖xe1† Or 30...♕xd3–+. 31.♕xe1 ♕xd3 ✓ 0–1

203.descr: Rustam Kasimdzhanov – Y.M.A. Kalandar Khaled, Macau 1996
203.solution: 23.♕d8†! An X-ray/reloader theme supported by the strongly-placed bishop on e4. 23...♖xd8 23...♕f8 24.♗h7†+– ✓ 24.♖xd8† ♕f8 25.♗h7†! Or 25.♖ed1 ♖c7 26.♗h7†±. 25...♔xh7 26.♖xf8± ✓ (1–0, 30 moves)

204.descr: Rustam Kasimdzhanov – Mohamad Al Modiahki, Teheran 1998
204.solution: 25.♖xd7! 1–0 Winning another pawn and exchanging some pieces. Too kind is 25.♗g4 ♗xg4 26.hxg4±. 25...♕xd7 26.♗g4 ♕d8 27.♗xc8 ♕xc8 28.♕xb5+– ✓

205.solution: 37.♕b8†! The breathing hole on g7 is not enough, neither is either of the two possible blocks on f8. 37.♗xe5? ♘g5† 38.♔g1 (38.♔g3 ♘xe4† 39.fxe4 ♕g5†–+) 38...♘xf3†–+ 37...♖xb8 38.♖xb8† ♔g7 38...♖f8 39.♗xe5† (39.♖xf8† ♕xf8 40.♗xe5†+–) 39...♕g7 40.♖xf8 mate ✓ 38...♕f8 39.♖xf8† ♖xf8 40.♗xe5† ♖f6 41.♗xf6 mate ✓ 39.♖g8 mate ✓

206.solution: 33...♕xh1†! Forcing a winning endgame. Not 33...♕h2† 34.♖xh2 gxh2† 35.♔h1 ♖g1† 36.♕xg1 hxg1=♕† 37.♔xg1⩱. 34.♔xh1 g2† 35.♔g1 ♗d4 ✓ With his material advantage and dangerous passed pawn, Black is winning. The game ended swiftly: 36.♕xd4† cxd4 37.♘xd6 ♘g5 0–1

208.solution: 38.♘e6!+– White is clearly better after other moves, but this finishes the game. 38...fxe6 The game try 38...g5 is plain hopeless; the game continued 39.♘xf8 (39.fxg6 and other moves are winning as well) 39...gxf4 40.♘fg6†! fxg6 41.♘xg6† and Black resigned. No better is 38...♕c8 39.♖xg7 ✓ with mate. 39.♘g6† ♔h7 40.♘xf8†+– ✓

209.solution: 36...h5†! Deflecting the king from the defence of the rook. 36...♘f6†? 37.♖xf6 ♖xf6 and all the pawns make up for the exchange. 37.♔xh5 ♖xf5 ✓ 0–1

210.descr: Veselin Topalov – Miguel Illescas Cordoba, Cala Galdana 1999
210.solution: 22.♘f6†! ✓ 1–0 Getting rid of the pesky knight on e3 with tempo, leaving White totally winning.

213.solution: White wins a pawn by exploiting the potential pin on the eighth rank, either by: 33.♘xc6! ♖xc6 34.♖b8 ♔h7 35.♖xd8+– ✓ 1–0 Or the almost equally good 33.♖a1, threatening ♖a1-a6, so 33...♘d5 34.♘xc6 with the same theme but having given away ...♘f6-d5.

214.solution: 31.b6! 1–0 The pawn queens after 31...♖xf7 32.bxa7+– ✓ and the threat on the rook leaves White a piece up after 31...♕xb6 32.♕xe7 ✓.

215.solution: 24...♖xc3 0–1 The rook on d3 is overloaded: 25.♖xc3 ♖xc3 26.♕xc3 ♕xd1–+ ✓

217.solution: 35...♗xh3! 0–1 Black is up too much material after 36.gxh3 ♕xh3† 37.♔g1 ♕g3† 38.♔h1 ♕f3† 39.♔g1 ♕xf6 ✓.

218.descr: Magnus Carlsen – Laurent Fressinet, Cap d’Agde 2006
218.solution: 27.♕f5! ✓ 1–0 Black is back-rank mated or loses the rook on e6.

219.descr: Vassily Ivanchuk – Magnus Carlsen, Monte Carlo (blindfold) 2011
219.solution: 14.♘db5 ✓ 1–0 Winning a pawn, with the bishop pair and d6-square, gives a decisive advantage. Somewhat weaker is winning the b6-pawn with: 14.♘cb5 ♕b8 15.♘xd6 ♕xd6 16.♘xc6 ♕xc6 17.♕d4+–

220.solution: 25.♘xc7! ♔xc7? Instead the game saw 25...♖d8 26.♘d5± when White had simply won a pawn, also stabilizing the knight on d5. 26.e6†+– ✓ White’s rook will penetrate to the seventh rank with devastating effect.

221.descr: Magnus Carlsen – Teimour Radjabov, Wijk aan Zee 2015
221.solution: 35.♗g7†! ♕xg7 36.♕xe8† ✓ With a winning advantage due to the two pawns, Black’s exposed king and the pawn-like bishop on b6. You don’t have to see any further.

222.descr: Magnus Carlsen – Sergey Karjakin, New York (rapid 4) 2016
222.solution: 50.♕h6† ✓ 1–0 What a way to finish a World Championship! It’s mate in one however Black takes back.

223.solution: 21...♗xd4†! 22.♔h1 22.cxd4 ♕xh2 mate ✓; Or 22.♖f2 ♕xh2†–+ when the crucial h2-pawn can be taken as both white pieces are pinned. 22...♖xg3–+ ✓ Black won a piece and soon the game.

224.solution: 23.♖xe6†! ♔xe6 23...fxe6 24.♗h6†+– ✓ wins the queen. 24.♕e4† ✓ ♔d7 White’s position is winning and you don’t have to see any further. Steinitz played: 25.♕xb7† ♔e6 26.♖e1† ♔f5 27.♕xf7† 27.♕e4 mate! 27...♔g4 28.♕f3† ♔h4 29.♕h3 mate

225.solution: 33...e3! Black had a dominant position and an extra pawn, so he could win slowly in many ways, but this is the quickest winner. 34.f3 Or 34.fxe3 ♖g6 quickly forces mate. 34...♖g6 ✓ It’s still a forced mate. 35.g4 fxg4 36.f4 ♗d5 37.♘d4 ♖a6 Pretty, but an even faster mate was possible with the prosaic 37...♖g2†. 38.♖xa6 ♖b1† 0–1 White resigned, rather than allow a mate such as: 39.♔h2 ♖h1† 40.♔g3 ♖g1† 41.♔h2 ♖g2† 42.♔h1 ♖g3† 43.♔h2 ♖h3† 44.♔g1 ♖h1 mate

226.solution: 13...♖de8†! 13...♖he8†! comes to the same thing. 14.♗xe8 ♖xe8† 15.♔f2 ♕e3† Or 15...♗c5† 16.♔g3 ♕h6! with a winning attack against the stranded king on g3. 16.♔f1 ♗xf3 17.gxf3 ♗c5! ✓ 0–1 The only move, with forced mate in two moves.

227.solution: 9.h3! ♕xg2 9...♕h5 10.g4+– ✓ also traps the queen. 10.♖h2+– ✓ Bird resigned after: 10...♕xh2 11.♘xh2 ♘xd4 12.♗b5†! 1–0

228.solution: 21.♘c6†! ♕xc6 21...♗xc6 22.♗xc5† ✓ ♔e8 23.♗xc6† ♕xc6 24.♕xd8 mate. 22.♗xc6 ♗xe3 22...♖xd2 23.♗xc5†+– ✓ comes with check and wins a rook. 23.♕b4† 1–0 Other moves were also winning.

229.solution: White has a winning position, but can push his advantage with 17.♕xg6!+– since Black cannot take back due to: 17...fxg6 18.f7† ♔d8 19.f8=♕† ♖xf8 20.♖xf8 mate ✓

231.solution: 14.♘e6†! The knight cannot be taken due to the discovered attack. 14...♔e8 14...fxe6 15.♗a5†+– ✓ and 14...dxe6 15.♗a5† ✓ wins the queen and the game. 15.♘bc7 mate ✓

232.solution: White is a pawn down, so has to create something. 19.♘ge6! fxe6 It would have been better for Black to give up the exchange on f8 with 19...g6⩲. With a pawn and opposite-coloured bishops for the exchange, Black has some compensation. Note that the bishop on b5 is essential after 19...g5 20.♘xf8 gxf4 21.♘d7!. ✓ Now, 21...♗d8 22.e5! is the only winning move, but that’s not necessary to see before sacrificing the knight. The point is 22...a6 23.exd6† ♔xd6 24.♘e5!+– threatening a fork on f7. 20.♘g6† ♔f7 The knight would not escape from h8 after 20...♔f6, but White has 21.♘xf8+– ✓. 21.♘xh8† ♔f6 The knight looks trapped, but it has two ways to escape. 22.f4 22.♖e3 is also good: 22...g5 23.♖f3† ♔g7 24.♖xf8 ♔xf8 25.dxe6± with a safe square on f7. 22...♘e7 23.e5†!+– ✓ ♔f5 24.♗d3†! 1–0 Not only can the white knight escape, the black king is mated!

233.solution: 14.♘c7†! ♔f8 14...♔e7 15.♕d6 mate ✓ 15.♕d6†! Forcing Black to set up a bank-rank mate. 15...♘ge7 16.♕d8†! Not 16.♘xa8? ♕a1† with some compensation for the exchange. 16...♘xd8 17.♖xd8 mate ✓

234.descr: C.E.A. Dupre – Wilhelm Steinitz, The Hague 1873
234.solution: 28.♘d6! c5 28...♖xd6 29.♕e8 ✓ mate is easy, but 28...♕xb2 ✓ is tricky. White’s best is to defend against the back-rank mate and take on d4 with the rook on the next move. Instead 29.♕xd4?! ♕xd4 30.♖xd4 is probably winning, but not easily. 29.♖xd4! ✓ 1–0 The check on e6 is decisive.

235.solution: If only Black had time for 24...b6 and 25...♔b7 – it’s not going to happen. 24.d5†! ♔b6 24...♕xd5 25.♗e4 ✓ wins the queen and 24...♔xd5 is not a nice move to play. There are many ways to stop the king from returning to “safety”, and the fastest is 25.♕h1† ♔c5 26.♗e3† ♗d4 27.♗xd4 mate. 24...♔d7 is not the direction the king wants to go. However, Black threatens to shut out White’s rook with 25...♗e5. Best is 25.♖e6!+– when White continues with 26.f6 or 26.♗b5†. 25.♗e3† 25.♖e4 also wins. Black’s king can’t go to c7 after 25...c5 26.♗d8†+–. 25...c5 26.♕d8†! The only winning move. 26...♕c7 27.♕xg8+– ✓ And White won. 27.♗g5 or 27.♕e8 should also win.

236.solution: 10...♘xd4!⩱ White loses the queen no matter which way he recaptures. 11.♗xf4 Steinitz played the unchallenging 11.c3. Also no help is 11.♕xd4 ♗c5–+ ✓ or 11.♘xd4 ♕xd1–+ ✓. 11...gxf4 11...♘xf3?! 12.♕d5!⩱ creates a pin along the fifth rank and wins back the piece. 12.♘xd4 Black did not win any material (he was a pawn up in the diagram), but destroying White’s centre is an achievement. 12...♕h4† 12...♕xd1 13.♖xd1⩱ is also good. However, due to White’s exposed king and undeveloped rook on h1, it’s more logical to keep on the queens. 13.♔g1 ♗c5⩱ Black continues with ...♘e7 or ...♘f6 and ...0–0.

237.solution: 23.♗xh6!+– White wins a pawn, since 23...gxh6? 24.♘f6† ♔h8 25.♘xe8 ✓ picks up the rook.

238.solution: 24.♖d7! Setting up a discovered attack. 24...♕xd7 25.♘h6† gxh6 26.♕xd7 ✓ Black resigned a move later.

240.solution: 12...d5!–+ ✓ Opening up for a pin on b4, winning a pawn to start with. 12...bxc4?! 13.♗xc4 (or 13.♗a4) 13...d5 14.♗b5!⩲ is not the way to exploit the exposed queen.

241.descr: G.H. Thornton – Wilhelm Steinitz, New York 1884
241.solution: 25.♖xf7! White undermines the defence of the rook on e6 while simultaneously defending e1, and doesn’t have to worry unduly about the check on f1. 25...♖xf7 26.♕xe6 ✓ 26.♖d8†± is about as strong. 26...♖f1† 27.♗e1 ♕b6 28.♕xb6?!± On account of Black’s open king, White should have kept the queens on the board with: 28.♕e2+– 28...axb6 29.♔d2 ♔g8 30.♖d8† ♗f8 31.♖d7?! Better is 31.♗g3 with a winning position. 31...♗d6 32.♔e2? ♖g1 33.♔f2 ♖h1 34.♔e2 ♖g1 ½–½

242.solution: 37...♖c8! 37...♗xg2? 38.♔xg2 ♖xd1 39.♖xd1 ♕g4† 40.♕g3 ♕xd1 and Black is better, but not winning. However, White should not win back the pawn with 41.♖xh6†? ♔xh6 42.♕h4† ♕h5 43.♕xd8 since the outside pawn majority decides after 43...♕g5† 44.♕xg5† ♔xg5. 38.♖xe4 38.♕xc8 ♕xd2 ✓ and the knight will fall, with mate following shortly. 38...♕xe4 ✓ 0–1 Black will win even more material, so White resigned. 38...fxe4? 39.♕xc8 ♕xd2 40.♕f5† is a perpetual.

243.descr: Isidor Gunsberg – Wilhelm Steinitz, New York (12) 1891
243.solution: 23.♖xd7†! Black actually has no defence even after 23.♖d2+– followed by 24.♖ad1. 23...♔xd7 24.♖d1† ♘d4 25.cxd4!+– ✓ There follows one or two lethal discovered checks. But not 25.♘xd4†? ♔e7 with an unclear position.

244.descr: Wilhelm Steinitz – Armand Blackmar, Skaneateles (blindfold simul) 1891
244.solution: 8.♘xe5! 8.♗xc6?! ♕xc6 9.♘xe5 ♗xd1 10.♘xc6 ♗xc2= 8...♗xd1 9.♘xd7 ♔xd7 Black has no time for 9...♗xc2 since the bishop on c5 is en prise: 10.♘xc5+– ✓ 10.♔xd1± White is a pawn up.

245.solution: 23.♖xd4! ✓ Steinitz keeps the dark-squared bishop, and can always attack on the dark squares with ♗xe6 and a few heavy pieces on the h-file. The position is winning, and the end came quickly in the game. Instead 23.♗xd4†? ♘xd4 24.♖xd4 is about even. 23...♘xd4 24.♖xh7† Forcing mate, but not obligatory to see since the alternative is easy enough: 24.♗xd4† ♖f6 and White is winning if the queen hurries towards h6 with a threat along the way. There are three ways: a) 25.♕b5 ♖ef8 26.♕g5+–, b) 25.♕d3 and c) 25.♕d1. 24...♔xh7 25.♕h1† ♔g7 26.♗h6† Or 26.♕h6† ♔f6 27.♕h4† ♔g7 28.♗h6† ♔h8 29.♗xf8 mate, or 29.♗g5† ♔g7 30.♕h6 mate. 26...♔f6 27.♕h4† ♔e5 28.♕xd4† Or 28.♕g3† ♔e4 29.♕e3† ♔f5 30.♕f4 mate. When the queen took on d4, Chigorin resigned instead of allowing 28...♔f5 29.g4 mate or 29.♕f4 mate.

246.descr: City of Liverpool – Wilhelm Steinitz, corr. 1893
246.solution: 20...♖xd5! 20...♘d4?! 21.♗e7! is a nice resource, with the point that White can take back twice on e7 with check – thus not giving Black time to capture on h5. Black has to play: 21...hxg6 22.fxg6 ♕xe7! (not 22...♗xg6?! 23.♕xg6 ♖xe7 24.♘xf6†+– or 22...♖xe7?! 23.♕h7† ♔f8 24.♘xf6+–) 23.♘xe7† ♖xe7 Black is not losing, but probably worse and certainly not winning as in the game. 21.exd5 ♘d4 22.♘e7† There is no defence against 22...♘xf5 23.♖xf5 hxg6 ✓ winning material. 22...♕xe7 ✓ It’s over, which White soon accepted.

247.solution: 29...♘xf2! 30.♘xf2 ♕e1† Black has a mating attack. 31.♔h2 31.♕f1 ♗xf2†–+ wins the queen and mates. 31...♗xf2 ✓ 32.h4 h5 0–1 Not the only way to mate, but the quickest.

248.solution: 19...♗xg3! 20.fxg3 ♖xf1† Including 20...♕e3† ruins nothing. 21.♕xf1 The point of the sacrifice is: 21.♔xf1 ♗xg4 22.♕xg4 ♕xc1†–+ ✓ 21...♗xg4 22.♕f4! ♕xf4 23.gxf4⩱ Black is a pawn up, but the opposite-coloured bishops give White fair hopes of making a draw; Schiffers did not manage though.

249.solution: 17.♖xe6! ♕xb5 17...♕xe6 18.♘c7†+– ✓ forks king and queen. 18.♗h6 18.♗d2 and 18.♗f4 are also winning. Black can’t move the king without giving up the pawn on f7, and 19.♖ae1 not only threatens the bishop on e7, but also the pawn on f6. 18...♔d8 19.♕xf7 ♖e8 20.♖ae1 ♕d7 21.♗g7 Black resigned three moves later.

250.descr: Wilhelm Steinitz – Emanuel Schiffers, Rostov on Don (2) 1896
250.solution: 13.♗xh6!+– Schiffers now accepted that he had lost a pawn. 13...gxh6 The game went 13...♕d7+– and White won after 41 moves. 14.♖xe6! The point of the sacrifice. 14...fxe6 15.♕g6† ♔h8 16.♕xh6† ♔g8 White can choose between picking up the knight on d5 with 17.♕xe6† ✓ or being more brilliant by continuing the attack with: 17.♕g6† ♔h8 18.♘g5 (or 18.♕h5† ♔g8 19.♕g4† ♔h8 20.♘g5+–) 18...♕e7 19.♕h5† ♔g8 20.♘xe6 There are also other ways to win.

251.solution: 25.♕d8† ♗f8 26.♖h8†! ♔xh8 27.♕xf8† ♔h7 28.♕xf7† ♔h8 29.♗xg6+– ✓ 1–0 Black can only avoid the mate by giving up his queen. 29.♕xg6+– also forces Black to give up the queen, but worse is 29.♕f6†?! ♔g8 30.♕xg6† when White captures the pawn with check, but Black can fight on after 30...♔f8+–.

252.solution: 35.♘ec5†! 35.♘bc5† is the same and 35.♘xd6 also wins, but only if White finds: 35...♔xd6 36.♗f4† ♔d5 (36...♔d7 37.♘c5† ♔e8 38.♗d6!+–) 37.♖e5† ♔c4 38.♘c5! White threatens mate- in-three with 39.♖c1† and the try 38...b4 39.b3†! ♔b5 40.♖xe7! ♗xe7 41.♖xe7! is hopeless (full points if you saw this far). White wins back the exchange after 41...♖b6 42.♗c7. White also has a winning position after 35.♗f4 ♘f5 36.♘bc5† ♔c7 37.♘a6†. 35...dxc5 36.♘xc5† ♔d6 37.♗f4† ✓ 37.♗xe7† is also winning and good enough for full points. The text move forces mate in five moves: 37...♔d5 38.♖e5† ♔c4 39.♖c1† ♔xd4 40.♘b3† ♔d3 41.♖c3 mate Or 41.♖e3 mate.

253.solution: 35...♗xg2! 36.♔xg2 ♕c6†–+ ✓ A double threat, winning back the piece and also another one. 36...♕b7†? 37.♔h2 ♕xb4⩲ only wins one piece. In the game, Steinitz tried to play on an exchange down with 37.♖e4 ♖xe4 38.♖xe4 ♕xe4† 39.♔g1, but in vain (0–1, 59 moves).

254.solution: 35.♗xc6! There is a looming check on e6. 35...f4 36.♖xf4! ♖xg3† 37.♔f2 Or 37.♔f1+–, but not 37.♔h2? ♖3g4⩱ and Black wins the bishop thanks to the mate on h4 if the rook protects the bishop. 37...♖h3 There is no perpetual or anything else compensating for the pawns after: 37...♔xc6 38.♖e6† ♔c5 39.♖xh6 ✓ ♖g2† 40.♔e3+– 38.♗d5+– With a lot of luck, Blackburne held half a point in a long endgame (½–½, 93 moves).

255.solution: 25.♘f6! gxf6 26.♕h4† Or 26.♗xf6† first. 26...♔g8 27.♗xf6+– ✓ The double threat against h8 and d8 wins material.

256.solution: 13.♘xe5! Loman played 13.♗xf7†?! ♔xf7 14.♘xg5†? (14.♘xe5† dxe5 15.♕xg4⩱), but he must have overlooked 14...♕xg5! 15.♗xg5 ♗xd1–+ with a fork on f3 (0–1, 22 moves). 13...♗xd1 13...dxe5 14.♕xg4+– ✓ doesn’t help. Instead, Black’s best try is 13...♘xb3 14.♕xg4 ✓ ♘xc1 (14...♘xa1 15.♗xg5! ♕c8 16.♕f4 [or 16.♕g3] 16...dxe5 17.♕xe5† ♕e6 18.♕xh8 with an almost winning advantage for White) White has a great initiative after 15.♘xf7± or he can win material with 15.♘f3±. 14.♗xf7† ♔e7 15.♘d5 mate ✓ Or 15.♗xg5 mate.

257.descr: Emanuel Lasker – Theodor von Scheve, Berlin 1890

258.solution: 34.♘xe6! ♗e8 34...♕xe6 35.♖g6+– ✓ 35.♖g6! The only move. 35...♕xg6 35...♗xg6 36.♕xh6† ♔g8 37.♘xf8! ♕xf8 38.♕xg6†+– ✓ 36.♕xg6 ♗xg6 37.♘xf8± ✓ White is a pawn up and Black’s bishop is a horrible piece, but it is not clear there is a way to force a win, although putting the king on h4 and then pushing the d-pawn seems very promising (1–0, 50 moves).

259.solution: 16.♗xg6!+– hxg6 After 16...♕f8 17.♗xh7†+– Black later turned the game around (0–1, 62 moves) but that had more to do with the nature of a simul than his actual chances in this position. 17.♕xg6† ♔h8 18.♕h6† ♔g8 19.♕xf4+– ✓ White picks up the rook.

260.solution: 28...♗xf2†! 29.♔h1–+ Black soon won. Capturing the bishop leads to mate: 29.♖xf2 ♖c1† 30.♖f1 ♕e3† 31.♔h1 ♖xf1 mate ✓ or 29.♔xf2 ♕e3 mate ✓.

261.solution: 12...♘xf4! 13.♗xf4 The game saw 13.♗b5∓ (0–1, 35 moves). It’s important that 13.♘xc6 ♘xe2†∓ ✓ comes with check. 13...♘xd4–+ ✓ By opening the c-file, Black creates play against c3 and threatens to win the bishop pair. 13...♗xd4? 14.♘d5⩱ is not correct – one pawn is not so much in this type of position; active pieces and attacking chances carry more weight.

262.solution: 14...♘xe4! 15.♗xe4 15.0–0 ♕c5†! is important, as otherwise White would have great compensation for the missing pawn. 16.♔h1 ♘f2† 17.♖xf2 ♕xf2∓ ✓; 15.♕f3!?⩱ is a way to play on a pawn down. Another way is the game move 15.♗e3∓ (1–0, 34 moves). 15...♕h4† 16.♔f1 ♕xe4–+ ✓ Now all talk of compensation can be dismissed.

263.descr: Alfred Ettlinger – Emanuel Lasker, New York (1) 1893
263.solution: 16.♘xc6! bxc6 17.♕xa6† ♔d7 18.♕xa2 ✓ Instead of being a pawn down, White is a pawn up. Therefore, he can bear placing the queen on b1 after: 18...♖a8 19.♕b1!± 19.♕c4?! ♖a1† 20.♘b1 f6⩲

264.solution: 20...♘xh2! 20...♕h5! works as well: 21.h3 ♘g1! And White has to give up the exchange since 22.♖ee1 ♘xh3–+ is Game Over. 21.♔xh2 21.♕d3 ♘g4–+ ✓ protects the bishop thanks to the mate threat. Or 21...♕h5–+. 21...♕h5† 22.♔g1 ♕xe2–+ ✓

265.descr: Harry Pillsbury – Emanuel Lasker, St Petersburg 1896
265.solution: 28...♕c3†! 29.♔a4 b5†! 30.♔xb5 ♕c4† 31.♔a5 ♗d8† 32.♕b6 So far, there was no other way to do it, but now Black has two moves. 32...♗xb6 mate ✓ Or 32...axb6 mate.

266.solution: 1.♕xf7†! 1.hxg7 ♕a2†! 2.♕xa2 ♘xa2 and White is only probably winning. 1...♔xf7 2.♘e7† ♗f3 3.♖xf3 mate ✓

267.solution: 7.♗xf7†! 7.♕d5? is a double threat, but 7...♕e7= defends. 7...♔xf7 8.♕d5† ♔e8 9.♕xc5± ✓

268.solution: 31...♖h1†! 31...♗xg3? 32.♘xg3 ♕h4 33.fxg4 ♕xg3 threatens 34...♖h2 35.♕e2 ♕h4 with mate, but 34.♖e3⩱ keeps the disadvantage to a minimum, as does 34.♕f3⩱. 32.♔xh1 ♗xg3! 33.♘xg3 33.♖e2 and Black has two ways: a) ♕h4† 34.♔g1 ♗h2† (or 34...♘f2–+) 35.♔h1 ♘f2† 36.♖xf2 ♗g3† 37.♔g1 ♗xf2 mate ✓ b) 33...♘f2† 34.♔g1 (34.♖xf2 ♕h4† 35.♔g1 ♗xf2 mate) 34...♘xd1 With an easily winning position. 33...♘f2† 34.♔g1 ♘xd1–+ ✓ White only gets a rook for the queen; there is no way to catch the knight on d1 without losing another piece.

269.solution: 25.d4! The queen has no squares and 25...cxd4 26.♖xc8† ♘xc8 27.♘xh6+– ✓ wins a piece.

270.solution: 1.♗xa6! bxa6 2.b5 axb5 3.axb5+– ✓ White queens. But not 3.a5?? b4–+.

271.descr: Emanuel Lasker – Manuel Marquez Sterling, Paris 1900
271.solution: 12.f5! The pawn sacrifice is good enough even on just positional grounds, but there is also a tactical follow-up. 12...gxf5 13.♗h6! 13.♘e7 ♕xa4 14.♘xf5 ♖g8! 15.♘xg7† ♖xg7 16.♕xf6 ♕xc2 gives some counterplay, although Black should not have enough for the piece after 17.♘c3 ♕xg2 18.♖f1±. 13...0–0 13...♗xh6 14.♕xf6 ✓ is a winning double attack and 13...bxc6 14.♗xg7+– was the game (1–0, 28 moves). 14.♕g3 Other moves are interesting as well, so full points if you have seen any of the other lines instead: 14.♗g5 ♘e4 15.♘e7† is winning, as is 14.♗xg7 ♔xg7 15.g4!. Even the immediate 14.g4 seems to give White a winning position. 14...♘e8 15.♘e7†! ♕xe7 16.♗xe8 ✓ f6+– White exchanged the “dead” knight on c6 for Black’s knight and is a piece up.

273.solution: 24...♖xh2†! 25.♔xh2 ♕h6† 25...♖h8†? 26.♔g1 ♕g6 allows White to almost escape: 27.♔f2 ♖h2 28.♔e1 ♘xg2† 29.♖xg2 ♖xg2 30.♖f2∓ 26.♔g1 ♘h3† White must give up his queen, with a losing position. 27.♔h2 Black soon won after 27.♕xh3 ♕xh3 ✓. 27...♘g5†!–+ ✓

274.solution: 39...♖h4! A beautiful and classic motif. 40.♔xh4 g5† 41.♔xg5 ♔g7–+

275.solution: 13.♗xc6†? bxc6 14.♕xc6† ♔f7 15.♕xa8 wins an exchange, but White loses: 15...exd4† 16.♔f2 ♗b7 and 17...♕e4–+. The exercise was a red herring! If he captures on c6, White has to limit the damage with 15.♕d5†! ♔g6 16.0–0!∓ with two pawns for the piece. But the best move is: 13.♗e2! ✓ To avoid the check on h5, Black should exchange queens with 13...exd4 14.♕xd4 ♕b4† 15.♕xb4 ♗xb4† 16.c3 when White has a slight advantage with fewer pawn islands. Other non-blundering 13th moves also give full points.

276.solution: 36...♖xh3†! Decisively opening up the king’s position. 37.gxh3 ♕xf3†! ✓ 38.♔h2 ♕g3† Or 38...♖g3 with mate in a few moves. 39.♔h1 f3 0–1 White resigned, as mate is on the way after 40.♖h2 f2.

277.solution: 22.♘xd6! 22.♗f4 would not spoil things enough to throw away the win, and 22.♖f1 hxg5 23.♘xd6 still gives White a winning attack. 22...cxd6 23.♕xd6† ♔b7 23...♔c8 24.♕c5† transposes. 24.♕d5† ✓ 1–0 Black cannot allow ♗e3†, ♕xe5† or ♕xa8†. So the only option was to resign.

278.solution: 1.d5! Another move order also works: 1.♗a6† ♔b8 2.d5! ♗d7 3.♗c4+– (or 3.dxc6 ♗xc6 4.♗c4+–) 1...cxd5 1...♗xd5 2.♗a6† and one of the pawns will queen with check (or 2.♗xd5+–). 2.♗a6† 2.c6 dxc4 3.b7† ♔b8 4.d7+– or 2.♗b3+– or 2.♗a2+– all also win. 2...♔b8 3.c6 ✓ 1–0 White is mating.

279.solution: 23.♘e6†! fxe6 24.♖xf4† ♔g8 24...♔e8 25.♗b5†+– ✓ and 24...♗f6 25.♖xd8†+– ✓ both fail to save Black. 25.♗xe6 mate ✓

280.solution: 23...♖xc2! 24.♕xd6 24.♕xc2 ♗f5–+; After the game move, there are many ways to win. The strongest is: 24...♖c1†! White loses the queen after: 25.♔xc1 ♖c8†–+ Another winning move is 24...♗e6!?–+ with two threats: a discovered check on a2 and 25...♖xf2.

281.descr: Emanuel Lasker – H.P. Fortuin Harreman, Netherlands (simul) 1908

282.solution: White can exploit Black’s back-rank problems. 21.♖ad1! ♖f8 22.♕d5†! 22.♖e8 eventually wins a piece, but the variations are complicated after 22...♕xa2. If you saw a full line of the following you get full points: a) 23.h4 h6 24.♖dd8! ♖xe8 25.♕xe8† ♔h7 26.h5!+– b) 23.h3 (23.f3 is similar) 23...h6 (23...h5 24.♖dd8! ♖xe8 25.♕xe8† ♔h7 26.♕xh5 mate) 24.g4!+– 22...♔h8 23.♕xf5!+– ✓

283.solution: 29...♘h3! 30.gxh3 Allowing the check on f2 is no alternative. 30...♗f3† Or with more flair: 30...♕f3† 31.♗xf3 ♗xf3 mate 31.♗xf3 ♕xf3 mate ✓

284.solution: 15.♗xg7! 15.♘h5!?± 15...♘xf2! 15...♔xg7 16.♘f5† ♔h8 17.♕xg4+– ✓ 16.♕d4!+– Retaining the bishop for the black knight leaves Black with a weaker king to take care of. The game instead continued 16.♔xf2 ♔xg7 17.♘f5† ♔h8 18.♕d4†! f6±, when White can take on a7. However, the pawn is not the main thing he has achieved, but instead the tremendous difference between the minor pieces. However, Black managed to turn the game around and win, which would have been less likely if White had found the strongest 16th move.

285.descr: Akiba Rubinstein – Emanuel Lasker, St Petersburg 1909
285.solution: 17.♖xc6†! bxc6 18.♕c1± Not 18.♕d2? ♖e5 and the undefended queen on d2 saves Black. In the game, White wins the whole rook and is a pawn up after: 18...♖xd4 19.fxe3 ♖d6 20.♖xf7± ✓

286.descr: Julio Lynch – Emanuel Lasker, Buenos Aires (simul) 1910
286.solution: 30...♖xe2! 31.♖xe2 ♖b1†! Precise. 31...♘xf4 32.♖e1 ♘xd5 33.exd5† does not win a pawn, even though Black is better due to the pawn structure. 32.♔g2 ♘xf4† 33.♔f3 ♘xe2 34.♔xe2 ♖b2† 35.♔f3 ♖xa2∓ ✓ White has decent drawing chances and managed to save himself in the game.

287.solution: 30...♘xe5!⩱ Black wins back his pawn, as 31.dxe5? d4–+ ✓ threatens to win not one but both rooks, as well as the bishop. The game continued 31.♘g3 (1–0, 58 moves).

288.solution: White can convert his positional advantage into a material advantage: 15.♗xh7†! ♔xh7 16.♕d3† ♔g8 17.♕xd7± ✓ (1–0, 41 moves)

289.solution: White is much better, and can tactically increase his advantage. 19.♕c3†! f6 20.♘xf6! ♖xf6 21.♗xh6†! ♔xh6 21...♔f7 22.♘g5†+– ✓ 22.♕xf6+– ✓ Black cannot challenge White’s queen. There are many ways to win, among them the moves in the game: 22...♗d7 23.♕f7 ♕g8 24.g5† The game ended here, and since it is mate-in-three it seems likely the supposed “0–1” result is a mistake.

290.solution: 1.a6! bxa6 2.♔d7! ✓ 1–0 Black cannot stop the pawn.

291.solution: 15.e6! fxe6 16.♕h5† g6 17.♕xc5+– ✓ Black is lost and walked into another tactic: 17...0–0–0 18.♗xe6 1–0

292.descr: Alexander Alekhine – Emanuel Lasker, New York 1924
292.solution: 28...♘g5! 29.♘xg5 Alekhine’s 29.♘e5 fxe5 30.♕xg5 e4–+ ✓ lost a piece. 29...♕h2† 30.♔f1 fxg5!–+ ✓ The double threat of 31...♕xh3 and 31...♕h1† 32.♔e2 ♕xg2 decides.

293.solution: White will soon regret putting baby in a (tight) corner! 15...♘g3†! 16.hxg3 hxg3† ✓ The king is trapped, so White has to give back the bishop, when he will fall apart on the dark squares and h-file. 17.♗h2 ♖xh2† 18.♔g1–+ Black has already won a pawn and wins by moving the next rook to h8, or using the b6-g1 diagonal (0–1, 27 moves).

294.solution: 23.♗xd6! cxd6 23...♗c8 was played in the game (1–0, 42 moves). 24.♘xd6+– ✓ Black’s queen cannot defend the bishop on d7 or rook on f7, so he loses an exchange.

295.solution: 21.♕d8†! ♕f8 22.♖xg7†! ♔xg7 23.♕g5† ♔f7 24.♕g6† ♔e7 25.♗g5† ✓ White has a mating attack; the game concluded: 25...♘f6 26.♗xf6† ♕xf6 27.♕xf6† ♔e8 28.♗g6 mate

296.solution: 24.♖e6!+– ✓ There is no defence against 25.♗xh6; taking on e6 opens up for mate on h7. Instead after 24.♗xh6? ♖xe1† 25.♔f2 ♔g8! 26.♗f4 ♖fe7 White has only a perpetual: 27.♕h7† ♔f7 28.♕g6† ♔g8=; 24.♖xe8? ♕xe8 25.♗xh6 is actually losing after: 25...♕e1† 26.♗f1 ♔g8 27.♗f4 ♗h4!–+

297.descr: A. Gavilan – Jose Raul Capablanca, Havana 1901
297.solution: 20...♗xh3! 21.gxh3 ♕xh3† 22.♔g1 ♕xg3†–+ ✓ The f2-pawn is pinned and White loses his knight on d3 (0–1, 39 moves).

298.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Juan Antonio Blanco Jimenez, Havana 1901
298.solution: 47.h4! The only winning move. 47...♔f4 48.h5 ♔g5 49.♔f7!+– ✓ Black is not in time to capture both pawns.

299.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Rudolf Raubitschek, New York 1906
299.solution: 32.♖xa7†! ♕xa7 33.♖a5! It’s mate on the next move. The game ended: 33...♕xa6 34.♖xa6 mate ✓

300.descr: Rudolf Raubitschek – Jose Raul Capablanca, New York 1906

301.descr: Albert Pulvermacher – Jose Raul Capablanca, New York 1907
301.solution: 10...♘xe4!–+ Black wins a piece, due to: 11.♗xd8 ♗f2 mate ✓

302.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Edward Adams, Washington DC 1907
302.solution: 37...♗b4! The sacrifice could be postponed a move, but not longer – White’s king was on the way to defend with ♔g2-f3-e4-d3. 38.axb4 ♖xd1 39.♘xd1 a3 ✓ 0–1 One of the pawns will queen.

303.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – William Pratt, Troy (simul) 1909
303.solution: 17...♖d7! 17...♖d5? 18.g4! and White is only slightly worse. 18.♘xh8 ♖e7! Black wins the bishop on c1, with a devastating pin along the first rank. 19.g3 ♖e1† 20.♔g2 ♖xc1–+ ✓ The game continued 21.d4 ♗d6 22.♘f7 h6 23.♘xd6† cxd6 24.♔f2 and Pratt won by collecting the kingside pawns while Capablanca released his knight (0–1, 43 moves).

304.descr: Juan Corzo y Prinzipe – Jose Raul Capablanca, Havana 1909
304.solution: 9.♘xe5! 9.♘f6† is a move order that also works. 9...♗xd1 10.♘f6† ♔f8 Or 10...gxf6 11.♗xf7† ♔f8 12.♗h6 mate ✓. 11.♘ed7† 11.♘fd7† also forces Black to give back the queen. 11...♕xd7 12.♘xd7† ♔e8 13.♖xd1 ♔xd7 14.♗xf7± ✓ White’s queen sacrifice won a pawn in the end (½–½, 76 moves). 14.e5 might be slightly stronger, and a few other moves also give a clear advantage.

305.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Einar Michelsen, New York 1910
305.solution: 27.♕xd5†! ♔c7 27...♔e8 28.♖e1† is Game Over and 28.♘d6† also leads to mate. 28.♕d6†! ✓ White is mating. 28...♔b6 29.♖b1† 29.♘fe7 and 29.♘ge7 are also winning. 29...♔a6 30.♕a3† Other moves are mating as well. 30...♘a5 31.♕d3†! 1–0 The only winning move, before Black creates an escape-square on b7.

306.descr: O. Tuka – Jose Raul Capablanca, Prague (simul) 1911
306.solution: 25.♘xe4! 25.♘b3 is also winning for White, again winning either the bishop or the knight. In the game, Black can’t take back due to 25...♕xe4 26.♗f3+– ✓ and if he doesn’t take, then he loses the bishop on c5 or the knight on e7.

307.descr: Jan Podhajsky – Jose Raul Capablanca, Prague (simul) 1911
307.solution: 21...♕h3!–+ ✓ There is no defence against 22...♖xf2. Capablanca played 21...♖f3?! 22.♔g2 ♕g4 and won after 23.♖h1 h5!–+ (0–1, 31 moves). However, 23.♖g1! h5 24.♔h2 would have held an equal position. 21...♖xf2? 22.♖xf2 ♕xg3† 23.♔h1 ♕xe3 24.♖g2 ♕xd4 25.♖xg5 hxg5∞ leads to a highly unusual position with five pawns for a rook.

308.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Edward Tennenwurzel, New York 1911
308.solution: 17.♘xf7! ♔xf7 18.♖xe4! dxe4 Tennenwurzel played 18...♗c8 ✓ and Capablanca had several ways to win. The easiest is 19.f5, when Black still can’t take on g5 or e4, and other moves are just losing. 19...dxe4 (19...♗xg5 20.♕h5†+– and White picks up almost everything) 20.♗c4† ♗e6 21.♕xh7! Not the only winning move, but the prettiest and strongest. 21...♘xh7 22.♘e5† ♔g8 23.♗xe6† ♔h8 24.♘g6 mate) 19.♗c4† ♗d5 20.♕f5†! ♔g8 21.♗xd5† Or 21.♕xd5†+–. 21...♔h8 Now, White wins with 22.♘e5 ✓, either immediately, or after capturing on a8, e7 or e4.

309.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – William Morris, New York 1911
309.solution: 26.♖e7! ♕xe7 27.♘xf5+– ✓ White not only threatens the queen, but also 28.♖xh7† ♔xh7 29.♕h5 mate.

310.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – J. Koksal, Prague (simul) 1911
310.solution: 22...♖xd3! 23.cxd3 ♖e2 The raking bishops together with the active rook give Black a winning attack. 24.d4 ♗xg2† 24...♗xd4 25.♗c3 gives some back-rank problems, but Black wins all the same after 25...♗xg2†! 26.♔h2 ♗c6†! 27.♔g3 ♗f2†! 28.♔g4 h5† 29.♔xh5 ♗f3† 30.♔g5 ♗e3† 31.♔h4 ♖g2 with ...♗g5 mate coming. 25.♔h2 ♗c6† 26.♔g1 26.♔g3 is forced mate: 26...♗d6† 27.♔h4 ♖e4† 28.♔h5 g6† 29.fxg6 hxg6† 30.♔g5 ♗e7† 31.♔h6 ♖h4 mate 26...♗xd4† 27.♔f1 ♗b5 28.♗c3 ♖xb2† 0–1

311.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Rudolf Spielmann, San Sebastian 1911
311.solution: 28.♗f4! Developing with tempo and defending against the mate. 28...♕d8 29.♖xe7!+– ✓ Black is mated, even after 29...♕f8 30.♕xg7†, as in the game (mate in 15).

312.descr: Wilhelm Kluxen – Jose Raul Capablanca, Hamburg (simul) 1911
312.solution: 17.♘g6†! ♕xg6 17...hxg6 18.♕h3† ♕h4 19.♕xh4 mate ✓ 18.♗xg6 ♖xf5 19.♗xf5+– ✓ The knight is trapped, so White wins a piece. 19...g6 20.♗e4 1–0

313.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Rolando Illa, Buenos Aires 1911
313.solution: 25.♕d7†! ♖e7 26.♖xg7†! ♔xg7 27.♕xe7† ♔h6 27...♖f7 28.♕xf7†! ♔xf7 29.♖xb6 axb6 ✓ White’s c-pawns are not impressive, but the outside passed pawn on the h-file secures the win. 28.♖g1± ✓ White has collected a second pawn and has good winning chances (1–0, 38 moves).

314.descr: Leopold Carranza – Jose Raul Capablanca, Buenos Aires 1911
314.solution: 12...♗xc2! Capturing a pawn that’s defended twice. 13.♗xc2 ♘c4∓ ✓ Black wins back the piece with an extra pawn.

315.descr: E. Weiss – Jose Raul Capablanca, Hamburg (simul) 1911
315.solution: 14.♖xg7†! ♔xg7 15.♗h6† ♔h8 16.♕g5 ♘h5 17.♖g1!+– ✓ There is no defence against 18.♗g7† followed by 19.♗f6†. Instead, 17.♕xh5 is not easily winning due to 17...♘d7!. Even though White gets two pieces for a rook after 18.♕xf7 ♖g8 19.♕xd7 ♗xc3 20.bxc3 ♕xc3 21.♕xd5±, Black has counterplay against the weak white king.

316.descr: Charles Jaffe – Jose Raul Capablanca, New York 1912
316.solution: 9...exd4! By opening the e-file, Black prepares 10...♘xe4. 10.cxd4 10.♗xf6 ♘c5! (10...♗xf6∓) The knight move threatens to capture the queen with check, and Black wins the e-pawn after 11.♕xd4 ♗xf6–+ ✓. 10...♘xe4–+ ✓ White has no compensation for the pawn (0–1, 31 moves).

317.solution: 18...♖xe5! 19.dxe5 19.♕xe5 ♘d3†–+ ✓ forks queen and king. 19...♗d3 ✓ Black wins the knight and, with the extra pawns and a strong continued attack, he has a winning position. The game continued 19...♘d3†? 20.♔f1 ♕xb5 21.♗xa5 ♕xa5∓ when Black is better, with two pawns and a better king for the exchange, but Capablanca later turned the game around (1–0, 42 moves).

318.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Juan Corzo y Prinzipe, Havana 1913
318.solution: 24.♗xg6! hxg6? Black should have accepted the loss of a pawn after 24...♗f6, but any bishop- retreat (b1, c2 or d3) gives White a huge advantage. For example: 25.♗b1 ♗xc3? 26.♖xe6! and White is winning even more material. 25.♕xg6† ♔h8 26.♖xe6+– ✓ Black has to give up a piece to prevent the heavy piece onslaught (1–0, 32 moves).

319.descr: R. Portela – Jose Raul Capablanca, Havana 1913
319.solution: 35...♖xd3†! 36.♖xd3 e4† 37.♔e3 37.♔g3 ♖g4†! is important: 38.♔f2 exd3 ✓ with a winning rook or pawn ending. 37...♖h3†! 37...exd3? 38.♔xd3 ♖xh2⩱ allows counterplay on the queenside. 38.♖g3 38.♔d4 ♖xd3† ✓ 39.♔c4–+ and the e-pawn queens if Black keeps the rook on the d-file. 38...♖xg3† 39.hxg3 exd3 40.♔xd3 ♔g4 ✓ The endgame can be evaluated as won without much calculation. The rest is given anyway, just in case. 41.♔c4 ♔xg3 41...b6 is easier. 42.♔c5 h5 43.♔b6 h4 44.♔xb7 h3 45.a5 h2 46.a6 h1=♕ 47.a7 c5† 48.♔b8 ♕h8† 49.♔b7 The remaining moves are strange in ChessBase. There are two ways to win: a) 49...♕g7† 50.♔b8 ♕f8† 51.♔b7 ♕e7† 52.♔b8 ♕e8† 53.♔b7 ♕b5† 54.♔c7 ♕a6 55.♔b8 ♕b6† 56.♔a8 c4! 57.bxc4 ♕c7 when White is not stalemated. 58.c5 ♕c8 mate; b) 49...♕xb2 50.a8=♕ ♕g2† 51.♔a7 ♕xa8† 52.♔xa8 ♔f4!–+ (but not 52...c4?? 53.bxc4 b3 54.c5 b2 55.c6 b1=♕ 56.c7 with a draw)

320.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Fedor Duz-Khotimirsky, St Petersburg 1913
320.solution: 28.♘f5! fxe6 28...gxf5 29.♕xf5 ✓ with unavoidable mate. Instead, the best defensive try is 28...♔h8 29.♕e4! (several other moves provide a clear advantage) 29...fxe6 30.♘xe7 ♕xe7 31.dxe6 ♘c3 32.♕xd4† ♕g7, but White is winning all the same. 29.dxe6! ♕c7 29...♕xf3 30.♘xe7† ✓ wins a piece, but there is no tactical way to finish the game after 29...♖b8. However, there is no need for it; White is winning if he avoids the queen exchange. 30.♕c6! ✓ Not obligatory, but a precise move that wins the b-pawn (1–0, 47 moves). 30.♕g4/g3 and 30.♘xe7† are also decent enough.

321.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Richard Reti, Vienna 1914

322.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – U. Kalske, Helsinki 1914
322.solution: 16...♖xf3! The two pieces are winning against the rook after whatever way White takes on f3. 17.♕xf3 ♘xg5–+ ✓

323.solution: 14.♘c4†! Or 14.♖xf6! gxf6 15.♘c4† dxc4 16.♘e4† ♔d5 17.♘xf6† ♔xd4 (17...♔d6 18.♘e4† ♔d5 19.♕h5† with mate) 18.♖d1† winning the queen. 14...dxc4 15.♘e4† ✓ With a mating attack. 15...♔d5 16.♖f5† 16.♖xf6+– reaches the line above, and 16.♕h5† wins as well. 16...♔xe4 16...♔xd4 17.c3† ♔d3 18.♖f3† ♔c2 19.♖f2† ♔d3 20.♘c5† mate 17.♖e1† ♔xd4 18.c3† ♔d3 19.♖d5 mate

324.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Joseph Blackburne, St Petersburg 1914
324.solution: White is winning after most moves, but can decide the game directly in a few moves: 28.♖xg7†! ♔xg7 29.♖g1† ♔f8 30.♕g6+– ✓ White threatens both a mating attack and the rook (which cannot escape or be protected anyway).

325.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Lynch/Villegas, Buenos Aires 1914

326.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – M. Wolfson, New York (simul) 1915
326.solution: 35...♖a2†! 36.♔xa2 ♕a4† Black resigned, as it’s mate: 37.♔b2 ♖e2† 38.♔c1 ♕c2 mate ✓

327.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – J.M. Stahr, Chicago 1915
327.solution: 33.♖xe6†! ✓ 33.♕xf5† exf5 34.♖xc7 ♖xg2† is probably winning for White, but he only keeps one of his pawns. Better is giving up a rook for the most important defender of the black position. 33...♔xe6 33...♔g5 34.♖d5+– pins the queen. 34.♕c6† 34.♕e2† ♕e5 35.♕xc4† ♔f6 36.♕f7† ♔g5 37.♖xc7 also wins. 34...♔e5 35.♖d5† 1–0

328.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Christoph Wolff, New York 1915
328.solution: 22...♖xe3! 23.fxe3 ♗xe3† If Black does not keep on the queens, White can safely continue with the counterplay on the queenside without fearing an attack: 23...♕xe3†?! 24.♕xe3 ♗xe3† 25.♔f1 ♗xc1 26.♘a4 ♗a3 27.♖a5 And White’s active pieces compensate for the material deficit. 24.♔h1 ♗xc1 Black has won two pawns, but Capablanca could have taken one back with 25.♘xd5! cxd5 26.♖xc1∓ ✓ when White has drawing chances.

329.descr: Walter Shipley – Jose Raul Capablanca, Philadelphia (simul) 1915
329.solution: 31...♖xf2! 32.♖xf2 ♘d3 The queen can’t defend both f2 and a1. But not 32...♕xf2†?? 33.♔xf2 ♘d3† 34.♔e3 ♘xc1 35.♖xc1+–. 33.♕d2 ♕xa1 ✓ 34.♖e2 ♕d4† 0–1 White resigned, as he is two pawns down.

330.descr: Manfred Schroeder – Jose Raul Capablanca, New York 1916
330.solution: 16...♗g3†! 17.hxg3 17.♔f1 ♘f2–+ ✓ with a fork. 17...♕xg3† 18.♔d2 ♘f2–+ ✓ The queen can’t defend the rook, and that’s only one of White’s problems.

331.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Marc Fonaroff, New York 1918
331.solution: 20.♘h6†! ♔h8 21.♕xe5! ♕xe5 22.♘xf7†!+– ✓ Black is mated or loses a piece.

332.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Walter Shipley, Philadelphia (simul) 1918
332.solution: 32...♘xa3†! 33.♖xa3 33.bxa3 ♕xc3! ✓ and White dearly misses his b-pawn. 33...♖xb2†! The game continued 33...♗xa3? 34.♘xb5! ♕xb5⩲ when Black was a pawn up, but Capablanca showed that the h-pawn is worth more than that. 34.♕xb2 ♗xa3 35.♕b3 ♖xh6∓ Now Black is two pawns up, although White has some counter-chances due to Black’s misplaced rook. However, note that he can’t play: 36.♕g8† ♔c7 37.♕g7† ♔b6 38.♕xh6 ♕b4† 39.♔a2 ♕b2 mate ✓

333.descr: Harold Cole – Jose Raul Capablanca, Hastings 1919
333.solution: 29...♗xf5! 29...♘xe4 30.♘xe4 ♕xe4 31.♕xe4 ♖xe4 32.♗h6 leaves White with some hope. 30.♕xf5 30.exf5 ♕e1† 31.♕f1 ♕xc3–+ ✓ also gives a position with two pawns extra. 30...♕xc3 ✓ 0–1 There is nothing dangerous happening on g7 due to the exposed white king, so the material advantage is decisive.

334.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Boris Kostic, Havana (3) 1919
334.solution: White already has two pawns, but Black threatens 29...♗xe1 and 29...♖d4. There is a solution to both of the threats: 29.♖e8! ♖d4 29...♖xe8 30.♖xe8† ♕xe8 31.♕xd5 ✓ wins, since Black can’t exploit the first rank. 30.♖xf8† Or 30.♕e6. 30...♗xf8 31.♕e6 ✓ White keeps both pawns with a serious advantage. 31.♕c1 is equally strong.

335.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Edward Tinsley, London (simul) 1919
335.solution: 17.♘h6†! gxh6 17...♔h8 18.♘xe4+– ✓ leaves White a piece up. 18.♘xe4 Threatening 19.♘f6†. The only defence is taking it, but after 18...♖xe4 19.♕xe4+– ✓ the compensation is clearly insufficient. The black king is open, his pawns are weak, and f4-f5 can be annoying at some point if Black does not further weaken himself with ...f7-f5.

336.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – T. Bray, Birmingham (simul) 1919
336.solution: 12.♘xf7! 12.♘e5! ♘xe5 13.dxe5 winning a piece, also gives full points, but only if you saw: 13...♕d5 14.♕f1! The knight cannot move due to 15.♗e4 winning the b7-bishop. 12...♗xf3 12...♔xf7 13.♘g5† ♔f8 (or 13...♔g8 14.♕xe6† ♔h8 15.♘f7† ♔g8 16.♘h6† ♔h8 17.♕g8† ♖xg8 18.♘f7 mate ✓) 14.♘xe6†+– ✓ A fork on the king and the queen. 13.gxf3 Also strong is 13.♕xe6 threatening mate, and 13...♗d5 14.♘xd8† ♗xe6 15.♘xe6 leaves White two pawns up with a positional advantage to boot. 13...♔xf7 14.♕xe6† ♔f8 15.♗c4 ✓ 1–0 There is no defence.

337.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Valentin Marin y Llovet, Barcelona (simul) 1920
337.solution: White has a pawn for the exchange, and with the king on b1 there would be hope. But 26...♖xa2†! 27.♕xa2 ♖a6–+ is brutal. The game ended: 28.♕xa6 ♕xa6† ✓ 29.♔b1 ♕d3† 0–1

338.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – M. Coll, Barcelona (simul) 1920
338.solution: 16.♘xf7! ♔xf7 The game continuation was 16...♕c7 17.♕xe6 ♗f8 18.♘xh6† ♔h8 19.♕g8† ♘xg8 20.♘f7 mate. 17.♕xe6† ♔f8 18.♗g6 ✓ Mate is unavoidable.

339.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – E.S. Maddock, New York (simul) 1922
339.solution: 25.♘xf6! ♗xf3 26.♗xf3! 26.♘xd7 ♗xe2 27.♘xe5 ♗xd1† 28.♔xd1 f6 is only slightly better for White, as the pawn on d3 falls. 26...♕d6 27.♗xe5 ✓ White can also start with 27.♗xb7†. 27...♕b6+– The point is 27...♕xe5 28.♗xb7† ♔b8 29.♘c6†+– ✓ with a fork. 28.♘xb7? Easier was 28.♗xb7† ♔b8 29.♘c6† ♔xb7 30.♘xd8† with too many pieces for the queen, and a decisive attack. 28...c4! Black threatens both 29...♕xb3† and 29...♕f2†, but Capablanca would still have been close to winning if he had played: 29.d4 ♕xb3† 30.♔d2 ♕b2† 31.♔e3 ♕xc3† 32.♔f2 Instead, the game continued 29.♘xd8 (1–0, 37 moves) but here Black could have drawn with 29...♕f2† 30.♖d2 cxd3† 31.♔c1 ♕e1† 32.♖d1 ♕e3† 33.♖d2 ♕e1†.

340.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Perkins, New York (simul) 1924
340.solution: 20...f4! 21.♖xh8 21.gxf4 exf4 22.♗xf4 ♘d4† 23.♔e3 and Black picks up an exchange with a winning position after 23...♘xc2† ✓. 21...♖xh8 22.gxf4 22.♘ce4 fxe3–+ was the hopeless game continuation (0–1, 27 moves). 22...exf4 23.♗xf4 ♘d4†–+ ✓ White loses the rook.

341.descr: Efim Bogoljubov – Jose Raul Capablanca, New York 1924
341.solution: Black has two not-so-strong pawns extra, but can increase his lead with: 31...♘xd4! 32.cxd4 ♖8xc5! 0–1 33.♖xc4 ♖xc4–+ ✓ moves the rook away from the threat, and White loses the rook on c1 after 33.dxc5 ♕xc5† 34.♔f1 ♖xc1–+ ✓.

342.descr: Frank Marshall – Jose Raul Capablanca, New York 1927
342.solution: 31...♖d5! 32.♕f3 32.♕c4 ♘e5 and the queen can no longer defend the rook on f1. 32...♘e5 ✓ The black pieces swarming around the white king will win the queen in one of several ways, for instance: 33.♕f2 ♖xf1† 33...♘d3 34.♕f3 ♖xf1† 35.♕xf1 ♘xb2 was another way to win. 34.♕xf1 ♘g4!–+ Black threatens 35...♘e3 and 35...♖d1 36.♕xd1 ♘f2†.

343.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – A. Souza Campos, Sao Paulo 1927
343.solution: 20.♖h3†! ♔g8 21.♘xf6†! ♔f8 21...gxf6 22.♗xf6 ✓ with mate on h8. 22.♖h8† ✓ ♔e7 There are now several ways to mate. 23.♖e8† 23.♘g8† ♔e8 24.♘h6† followed by 25.♗(x)f7 mate is equally fast. 23...♖xe8 24.♖xd7† ♔f8 25.♖xf7 mate

344.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – C.H. Reid, London 1928
344.solution: 17...♖xh4†! The move order 17...♗xg2 works as well, as 18.♘xg2 loses to 18...h4. But 17...♖hg8 18.♗h3! is not as clear, although probably still winning after 18...f5. 18.gxh4 ♗xg2 19.♔xg2 19.fxe5 was the hopeless game continuation: 19...♕h3† 20.♔g1 ♗xf1 and White resigned. 19...♕g4† 20.♔f2 ♕xh4† ✓ 20...♘d4 21.♗xd4 ♕xf4† also wins. 21.♔f3 White has to give up several pieces to avoid mate after for example: 21...♘d4† 22.♔e4 f5† 23.♔d5 ♕f6–+

345.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Gracie Square Pharmacy Chess Club, New York (simul) 1931
345.solution: 37.f6†! Black has to take on f6 to defend the g6-pawn. 37...♖fxf6 38.♘h5† ♔h7? No better is 38...♔h8 39.♕h6† ♔g8 40.♕g7 mate ✓. Black had to play 38...♔f7 39.♖xf6† ♖xf6 40.♕xf6† ♔e8. Without rooks, he threatens both 41...bxa2 and a lot of checks. The trick is to take on g6, defend the f1-square and the e4-pawn with check, and then take on b3: 41.♕xg6† ✓ ♔d8 42.♕f6† ♔c7 43.♕f4† ♔b7 44.axb3+– 39.♘xf6† ✓ White can take care of the black counter- threats in more than one way, for instance: 39...♔g7 40.♘h5† ♔h7 41.♕e7† ♔h6 42.♘g3+– The knight moves back to g3.

346.solution: 17.♗xf7†! ♔h7 17...♕xf7 18.♘xh6†+– ✓ A fork. 17...♔xf7 18.♕b3† ♔e8 (or 18...♘d5 19.exd5 gxf5 20.dxc6† ✓ ♔g7 21.cxd7 ♗xd7 22.♘xe5+– with three pawns more) 19.♕e6† ♕e7 20.♕xe7 mate ✓ 18.♗xg6†! ♔xg6 19.dxe5+– ✓ 20.e6 and 21.e7 or 21.♘e5 wins material wherever Black moves the knight.

347.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – George Thomas, Hastings 1934
347.solution: 24...♕a5–+ ✓ A double threat against the bishop and knight. Thomas started with 24...♖xd2?! 25.♖xd2 before playing 25...♕a5. He was winning, and won, but there was little reason to give away the exchange. Perhaps he feared the knight coming to d6, but apart from giving up the exchange when that happens, he could also win with: 25.♘c4 ♖xd1! 26.♖xd1 26.♘xa5 ♖xe1† 27.♗f1 ♗a6–+ 26...♕xb5 27.♘d6 ♕d7 When all is well and safe.

348.solution: 19.♕xh7† 19.♖xf4? ♖xf4–+ 19...♔f7 20.♖xf4†! ♕xf4 21.♖f1 ♕xf1† 22.♗xf1+– ✓ Black has no chance of surviving, with his poor development and weak king. Or 22.♔xf1+–.

349.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – Andor Lilienthal, Moscow 1936
349.solution: 35.♘xb7! ♖xb7 35...♘xc4! is the best defence. White is a pawn up after 36.♗xc6†± but there is work left to do to convert. 36.♗xc6† ♖d7+– ✓ It is possible to imagine a situation where Black blockades the queenside pawns, but it is not realistic with careful play. Best is the game move: 37.c5 (1–0, 54 moves)

350.descr: Jose Raul Capablanca – J.C. Rather, New York (simul) 1936

351.solution: 21.♖h7†! ♔xh7 22.♕h5† ♔g8 22...♔g7 23.♕h6† ✓ ♔g8 24.♖h1 with mate. 23.♗xg6 There are other ways to win, but this is the cleanest. 23...fxg6 24.♕xg6† ♔h8 25.♖h1 mate ✓

352.solution: White’s king seems reasonably safe in the centre, but with 19...♖xd4†! Black exposes it to the deadly onslaught of his entire army. 20.exd4 ♗f4† 21.♔d1 ♕xd4† 22.♕d3 ♕xd3 mate ✓

353.solution: 14.♘xe5! ♗xd1 The game went 14...♘xe5 15.♕xh5+– ✓. 15.♗xf7† ♔f8 16.♘xc6 This wins back the queen. Also good is the long but forcing variation 16.♗d5† ♔e8 17.♗xc6† ♔e7 18.♘g6† ♔e6 19.♗d5† ♔d7 20.♖f7† ♔c8 21.♘e7† ♕xe7 22.♖xe7±. 16...♕d7 17.♗e6†± ✓ White is two pawns up and has good winning chances.

354.solution: 27...♘f2! Zhukovsky played 27...♕b5†? when strongest is 28.c4!∞ to open the third rank for the queen. 27...♘h2†? 28.♔g1 ♘f3† also fails to win after: 29.♔h1 ♖g8! (threatening 30...♕xh3† 31.hxg3 g2 mate) 30.♗xg3! ♖xg3 31.♕f8†= It’s almost a perpetual, and if not then White can defend the knight on h3. 28.♔g1 28.♗xg3 ♘xh3! 29.gxh3 ♕f3† ✓ leads to mate, as does 28.♘xf2 ♕e2† 29.♔g1 ♕e1† 30.♖xe1 ♖xe1 mate ✓. 28...♘xh3†! 29.gxh3 ♕xh3! ✓ White will be mated. 29...♕e2 30.♗xg3 ♕e3† 31.♔h2 ♕f3! 32.♖e1 ♖d8! is also mating.

356.solution: 23.♗xg6! ♘xg6 24.♕xe6† ♔h8 25.♕xg6 ✓ White threatens 26.♖f7 or moving the queen with check followed by g5-g6. It is a forced mate. The game ended with: 25...♕c6 26.♕h5† ♔g8 27.♕f7† ♔h8 28.g6 d4† 29.♘d5 1–0

358.descr: Alexander Alekhine – Dawid Daniuszewski, St Petersburg 1909
358.solution: Black is positionally winning and after 34...♕xg6! 35.fxg6 ♖xf1–+ ✓ he also wins material. White’s queen cannot escape. The double threat with 34...♕c4 picks up a pawn, and if you are 100% sure you would win this, you can give yourself full points (hand on your heart!).

359.solution: 21.♘d5†! ♔e8 21...exd5 22.♖ae1†+– ✓ followed by 23.♖xf8. 22.♘xc7† ♔e7 23.♘d5† ♔e8± ✓ The knight retreats to e3, with or without the exchange on f8.

360.solution: 20.♖xf7! ♕xf7 21.♘b6† axb6 22.♗xf7 ✓ If Black had time to move the knight and take on h4, he would have compensation for the exchange. But there is no hope after: 22...♘f6 23.hxg5+–

361.solution: 14.♗h6! 14.♘xg7? ♔xg7 15.♗h6† ♔h8 is not mating. 14...♘e8 14...gxh6 15.♕xh6+– ✓ threatens mate both on g7 and h7. The best defence was 14...g6, since Black gets the bishop pair if White takes the exchange. But 15.♘g7! puts an end to that dream. 15.♗xg7! An important move – otherwise 14.♗h6 makes no sense. 15...♘xg7 16.♕h6+– ✓

362.solution: 21...♘xc3! 22.♗xg6 22.♕xc3 ♗xe4–+ ✓ is over, and Black wins an exchange after 22.♗xa8 ♘xb1–+ ✓ (not 22...♘xd1?! 23.♗f3∓ and the knight is trapped). After the game move, there are many ways to win: capturing a rook or creating a double threat against g2 and g5. Alekhine chose: 22...♕d5 23.♗xh7† ♔h8 24.f4 ♘xb1 25.♖xb1 ♕xd4†–+

363.descr: Alexander Alekhine – Boris Koyalovich, St Petersburg 1912
363.solution: 34...♗d4! Black defends against 35.♕f6† or 35.♕xh8†. 35.♖xd4 ♗xc4†! 36.♔f2 No salvation is offered by 36.♖xc4 ♕xc4†–+ ✓ or 36.♔g2 ♗f1†–+. 36...♖h2†! The king will be forced to a light square, allowing the bishop to move with check. 37.♔g3 37.♖g2 ♖e2† (or 37...♖xg2† 38.♔xg2 ♗f1† 39.♔xf1 ♕xc3–+) 38.♗xe2 ♕xg2† 39.♔e3 ♕xe2 mate ✓ 37...♖h3†! The only winning move. 38.♔xh3 ♗f1†! 39.♖xf1 ♕xc3–+ ✓

364.solution: 16.♘cd6†! White wins the exchange or the queen with a discovered attack. 16...♗xd6 17.♘c7† ♖xc7 18.♕xa6+– ✓

365.descr: Alexander Alekhine – Efim Bogoljubov, St Petersburg 1913
365.solution: 21...♖xf2! 22.♗xf7† The two captures are hit hard: 22.♖xf2 ♖e1† 23.♖f1 ♖xf1 mate ✓ and 22.♕xf4 ♖xg2 mate ✓. 22...♔h8! ✓ White is still mated if he captures the rook or the queen, and 23.♖d1 ♕xf7–+ also gave no hope (0–1, 27 moves). Or 23...♖xg2†–+.

366.descr: Sergey Lebedev – Alexander Alekhine, St Petersburg 1914
366.solution: 23...♖c2! White has three ways to defend against 24...♖xb2, but none helps. 24.♖xc2 a) 24.♘c4 ♗xf4 25.exf4 ♕d4!–+ ✓ Black does not have to exploit the pin. Next is 26...♗xf3. b) 24.♘xd3 ♖xc1† (24...♗d6–+ also wins a piece) 25.♘xc1 a5!–+ ✓ The knight on d2 is lost. 24...dxc2†–+ ✓ 25.♔xc2 Black is not in a hurry, but there is a way to end the game that’s easier than the others: 25...♖c8† 26.♔b1 Or 26.♔d1 ♗xf3† mating. 26...a5!–+ The next move is 27...♕xd2.

367.solution: 40.♖g8†! The rook sacrifice ensures that the next moves come with check. 40.♖h7†? ♔xh7 41.♕xe4† ♖f5 42.♗xd6 ♕xf3⩲ gives counterplay with the d4-pawn alive. 40...♖xg8 41.♕xd4†! ♔h7 42.♕xe4† ♖g6 42...♔h8 and White wins by taking on d6 now or after a few checks. 43.♗xd6+– ✓ Exchanging first was also winning. The rook is no match for the connected passed pawns supported by the bishop.

368.solution: 28...♖xg2†! 29.♔xg2 d4†–+ ✓ 29...♖g8† is also mating in various ways, and 29...♕g4† as well as 29...♗g5 are also winning. 30.♗e4 The point of 29...d4† is shown after 30...♖g8† 31.♔f1 ♕xf4† when White can’t defend the check with ♕f2. One way to end the game is: 32.♔e2 ♕xe4† 33.♔d1 ♕d3 mate

369.solution: 15.♘f7! 15.♘c6 ♗xc6 16.♕xe6† ♔h8 17.♕xc6+– wins a pawn (one point). 15...♔xf7 16.♕xe6†! ♔g6 16...♔xe6 17.♘g5 mate ✓ is over, and Black has to give up too much to avoid mate after 16...♔f8 17.♘g5+– ✓. 17.g4 18.♗xf5 mate and 18.♘h4 mate are two threats Black can’t defend against. Also mating are 17.♗xf5† ♔h5 18.g4† ♘xg4 19.♗xg4 mate and 17.♘h4† ♔h5 18.♕xf5†, with mate on the next move. 17...♗e4 18.♘h4 mate ✓

371.solution: 27...♕xh2†! 27...♕xg4† 28.♖g2 ♕xf5∓ leaves White fighting. 28.♔xh2 ♘xg4† 29.♔g3 ♘xe3–+ ✓ Black takes on f5 and wins two pawns and an exchange with no counterplay left for White.

372.solution: 23.♘xf7! ✓ ♔xf7 White also wins a pawn after 23...♗xf7 24.♗xf7± (24.♖xe7±). 24.♖xe6 24.♗xe6†± is good enough, but the text move is stronger. 24...♘d5 25.♖e7†+– (1–0, 36 moves)

373.solution: 17...♘xc4!∓ Black wins a pawn due to: 18.♕xc4 d5 19.♕b5 a6!–+ ✓ The only good move.

374.descr: Alexander Alekhine – G. Resser, The Hague (simul) 1921
374.solution: 35.♕f6†! ♔e8 36.e6! White does not have to move with check – Black’s counterplay is too slow. 36...♕f5! A strong defence, forcing White to find the only way to win. 36...♕g6 37.exf7† (or 37.♕h8† ♔e7 38.♗c5†!+–) 37...♕xf7 38.♖e6† ♔f8 39.♕xh6†+– And Black must give up the queen for the rook (or 39.♕h8†+–). 37.exf7† ♔f8 38.♗c5†! ♖xc5 39.♕xd8† ♔xf7 40.♖b7†! ✓ 1–0 Black will be mated.

375.descr: Joaquin Torres Caravaca – Alexander Alekhine, Spain (simul) 1922

376.solution: Black is almost getting mated, and can take a perpetual check, but more can be achieved: 38...♖8c3†! 38...♖1c3† makes no difference. 39.bxc3 ♖xc3† 40.♗d3 ♕f1†! 41.♔e3 ♖xd3† 42.♕xd3 ♕xd3† 43.♔xd3 ♔xf7–+ ✓ White’s ruined pawn structure makes him a hopeless victim.

377.solution: 18.♘xc6!± White won a pawn due to: 18...♗xc6 19.♖xc6 ♖xc6 20.♕xe4 dxe4 21.♖xd8+– ✓

378.descr: Alexander Alekhine – Manuel Golmayo de la Torriente, Spain 1922
